Despite his innings and Aneurin Donald's 36, Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in cloudy conditions, with Glamorgan eventually bowled out for 220 after securing a bonus point. Gloucestershire struggled in reply during the evening gloom, leaving the day evenly balanced. Michael Hogan is captaining Glamorgan in place of the injured

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police after discussing a planned murder bid online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court related to threats made on two occasions while drunk. The plan involved making a false police report to ambush and shoot officers on the Dee Estuary. Hughes, who has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009, was remanded in custody pending sentencing next week. His legal team stated he would not have carried out the threats. At the time, North Wales Police were concerned as Hughes was on bail for firearms offences, of which he was subsequently cleared.

At 07:00 BST, the crew of a 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards because a pump on board could not handle the amount of water coming in. The RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a pump on the vessel and towing it to Holyhead.

Laura Muir will miss the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast in April because her veterinary medicine exams are in May. The 24-year-old middle-distance runner, who recently finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, is returning to university for her final year. Despite being "gutted" to miss the opportunity to run for Scotland, she prioritizes completing her degree. Muir achieved a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m at the championships. She considers the World Indoor Championships in March a "potentially a target" and believes she has potential for future Olympics.

A new £45m facility is planned for Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, which will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council intends to ask the McIlvanney family for permission to name the campus in honour of the renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock and was passionate about education. McIlvanney, initially an English teacher, became a full-time writer in 1975, gaining recognition with his first novel, "Remedy Is None", and earning the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir" through works like the Laidlaw trilogy. He was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster, contributing to Scotland's political and sporting life. McIlvanney died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near the swimming pool was evacuated, affecting three streets, while residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors near walls with windows open due to a sea mine spotted on Monday. The mine is thought to be British from the 1940s or 1950s. Exclusion zones remain on the river and at sea (half a mile), affecting small boats and causing some disruption to Caledonian MacBrayne ferry services. Police stated the evacuation was precautionary with no immediate danger. The Royal Navy noted the mine's deterioration made its explosive content uncertain, leading to a decision to move it to a safer place before dealing with it. Inverclyde Council thanked residents for their patience.

UK Sport will invest £345m in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo 2020 Games, slightly less than the £347m allocated for Rio. Team GB has been set a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton, have had their funding removed entirely. Cycling's funding was cut by over £4m. Badminton England expressed shock at the decision, calling it "incomprehensible" after winning a bronze medal in Rio. UK Sport justified the cuts by stating the need to prioritise funding to protect and enhance medal potential. Basketball, volleyball, and handball criticised UK Sport's perceived lack of interest in funding team sports development. Funding for newly added sports like baseball/softball is yet to be confirmed, with £9m still to be allocated based on medal potential.

Three Victorian hotels (Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and The Ocean View) in East Cliff, Bournemouth, are to be demolished to make way for a new development by The East Cliff Project LLP. The new development will include a six-storey, 90-room, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (one nine-storey, one seven-storey) containing 122 apartments, located on Grove Road and East Overcliff Drive. Despite strong objections from English Heritage regarding the scale causing "severe harm" to the designated conservation area, and objections from 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society about losing historic character, councillors voted 7-3 in favour. Supporters, including Councillor David Kelsey and 246 letter writers, argued the plan would aid tourism, improve living for older people, and replace buildings deemed no longer functional.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was killed after being punched and beaten by Jake Vallely, 24, during a night out in Brecon on 8 May. Pte Boyd, who served with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment and was in Brecon for training, was found unconscious by police. Vallely, who had been drinking heavily and boasting he was the "hardest man in Brecon", was seen on CCTV attacking Pte Boyd outside The Cellar bar and dragging his body. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. His friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Police called the attack "despicable," and Pte Boyd's family paid tribute, describing him as loving and caring with a promising career cut short, leaving an unbearable void.

Andrew Travers left his role at the authority by "mutual agreement" following an error where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched by the council, which will conclude by the end of May with findings presented publicly. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over the role. Barnet Council apologised for the problems and offered emergency proxy votes, though voters questioned the fairness of the result. Mr Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the issues. The investigation will also review arrangements for the EU Referendum.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored first for Gateshead with a free-kick, but Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with a similar set-piece before half-time. Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead with a header from Craig Baxter's cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby felt his team improved significantly in the second half after a disappointing first half, praising the winning goal. Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment, stating his team's second-half performance was weaker than the first and that they failed to convert chances.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 across 96 countries. Norway is ranked as the top country according to this index, while Afghanistan is ranked the worst, followed by Mozambique.

Standard accessible toilets are often inadequate for people with severe disabilities who may need assistance from carers or require equipment like hoists and changing benches. The lack of suitable facilities, known as Changing Places toilets, can lead to isolation, stress, and undignified situations, such as changing individuals on toilet floors. Changing Places toilets are larger than standard accessible ones and include extra features to meet these needs. While recommendations for installing them in larger public buildings have existed since 2009 (BS 8300:2009), campaigners, including families affected, are pushing for these guidelines to become compulsory in building regulations for new, large complexes like shopping centres and stadiums. Challenges include space requirements (12 sq metres) and costs, particularly for existing buildings. However, examples like Arsenal FC show successful installation and positive reception.

A formal complaint has been made to the European Commission by Italian consumers' organisations, supported by the SEIU and European unions, accusing McDonald's of abusing its dominant market position. The complaint alleges that McDonald's forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, uses longer-than-average contracts preventing switches to competitors, and leases premises at above-market

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh has emerged to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The diagnosis occurred unexpectedly during an operation for his appendix at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast, where doctors found and removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. The hashtag was initially used by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff, on their Facebook and Instagram posts to encourage prayer from the congregation. It subsequently went viral, reaching over 79,000 people worldwide. A large poster featuring the hashtag also appeared in Holywood by the A2, paid for by an anonymous donor. The church and family are amazed by the global outpouring of support, which includes classmates using the hashtag on Twitter.

As part of a UK military building shake-up, Brecon Barracks is set to close. Local Conservative MP Chris Davies condemned the decision, highlighting the barracks' long history since 1805 and its importance to the military town. He is launching a petition against the closure, expressing concerns about local unemployment and military tourism, although the 85 civilian and 90 military jobs are not thought to be at risk. The nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school are expected to remain unaffected. Other changes include creating a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, the closure of Cawdor Barracks in 2024, and a

A House of Lords report examines the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. While many in the industry supported leaving the EU to escape the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and regain control of UK waters, the report warns they risk being marginalized in negotiations due to the sector's small economic contribution. Key complexities include shared fish stocks with EU states, the UK's reliance on exporting fish to the EU, and importing fish consumed domestically from the EU. Continued access to EU markets is deemed necessary but may require granting EU boats access to UK waters as a trade-off. The report suggests retaining some CFP elements, basing quotas on science, and notes potential issues with managing fisheries separately within the UK post-Brexit. Despite these warnings, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about controlling UK waters and becoming a leading fish-exporting nation, buoyed by recent quota increases. The government states it aims for maximum trade freedom and will review fisheries management.

OpenAI is a research venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. Its stated goal is to advance digital intelligence to benefit humanity as a whole, unconstrained by the need for financial return, aiming for a "positive human impact". This initiative exists alongside warnings from figures like Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking about the potential existential threats posed by AI, although other experts consider such risks remote. OpenAI believes AI should be an extension of human will and distributed broadly and safely. The venture has $1bn pledged, but only a small fraction will be spent in the near term.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26th. Despite a brain injury that initially took his speech, he has fought back, regained his speech unaided, and retains his personality and humour. He spends 12 hours a day in rehab and raises money for military charities, including the Pilgrim Bandits. Since carrying the torch, he has received thousands of Facebook friend requests, exceeding the 5,000 limit for personal pages. The public support has been described as "phenomenal" by his mother, leaving Ben "buoyed up." Facebook suggested he could use a public page or the subscribe feature instead.

In 2011, the US poverty rate was 15%, affecting 46.2 million people, and remained unchanged after three previous years of increases. Real median household income fell by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, saw its first annual increase since 1993, rising by 1.6%. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. The poverty rate in 2010 had reached a record high of 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, 25, has signed a new contract with Lancashire (Red Rose) until 2019, having moved from Somerset in 2013. A short-format specialist, he holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent, his contribution to winning the T20 Blast final, his positive dressing room presence, and the value of his international experience to the squad. Buttler, who has been playing in the IPL for Mumbai Indians, will return for Lancashire's T20 Blast game against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, Campbeltown, Chatham, and Cornwall) are moored in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting disposal. The bidding process is underway, with interested parties finalising bids after a January registration deadline; no preservation proposals were submitted. Viewings are set for late February/March, with a decision expected in spring. The Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess industry capacity. MP Penny Mordaunt supports UK recyclers but also hopes one ship can be saved, favouring a reef/diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence seeks the best financial return. Type 22 frigates were versatile warships, often serving as flagships with around 280 crew. HMS Ark Royal was previously sold as scrap for £3m.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced instability and international isolation due to racial and political tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. This period saw coups in 1987, 2000, and 2006, which harmed the economy, particularly tourism, and damaged Fiji's international reputation, leading to a temporary suspension from the Commonwealth. These events prompted many Indo-Fijians to emigrate, resulting in indigenous Fijians becoming the majority population, though informal segregation remains deep. Following elections in 2014, Fiji was reinstated into the Commonwealth, and diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand were restored. Fiji's economy relies on sugar and tourism but also includes mining and services; however, it faces persistent deficits and depends heavily on foreign aid.

The passage discusses the shortlist for the 46th Booker Prize. Mukherjee's *The Lives Of Others* is the 5/2 favourite to win. This is the first year the prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced on Tuesday night at London's Guildhall.

The shortlist includes Mukherjee, former winner Howard Jacobson (*J*), Ali Smith (*How To Be Both*), Joshua Ferris (*To Rise Again at a Decent Hour*), Karen

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing to the Supreme Court after an Appeal Court lifted a ban preventing him from being named in the media in England and Wales. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish details of alleged extra-marital activities, including a three-way sexual encounter, which PJS argues violates his right to privacy. An initial injunction blocking identification was overturned by the Appeal Court because the story had already been published internationally and online, making confidentiality likely lost. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal, and an interim injunction preventing PJS from being named remains in place until the hearing concludes.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was purchased in August for £345.5m. The new owners, Crown Estates, are preparing plans to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units and common areas. They have met with Blaby District Council regarding potential planning questions. The improvements aim to address the park's "tired" look, enhance its role as the "gateway from Blaby into the city," and improve the quality of walking and parking areas and facilities.

The live-action film "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy in Malaysia due to an "exclusively gay moment" involving the character LeFou. Its release was initially held for a content review. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) subsequently approved the film for screening with a "minor edit concerning a gay moment" and granted it a P13 parental guidance classification. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia. A new release date has not yet been announced, and local cinemas have offered refunds for advance ticket purchases. The decision to review the film drew criticism from netizens.

Landlords letting properties to more than three unrelated people in Southampton require a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost £1,000. Despite facing fines up to £20,000, many landlords are deterred by the cost, with Southampton City Council estimating 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Tenants in HMOs frequently express concerns about eviction fears and poor property maintenance, linked to a shortage of affordable housing forcing them into unregulated rentals, according to Shelter. Southampton's licensing applies in specific designated areas introduced in 2013 and 2015, differing from national rules. While most landlords cooperate, the council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) are seeking to avoid a second election after the previous one, almost two months ago, resulted in no party being able to form a majority government (FG 50 seats, FF 44, SF 23, Labour 7) and TDs failing to elect a Taoiseach. Mr Martin has indicated Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but not support its programme. Water charges are a primary obstacle, with Fianna Fáil wanting their immediate removal and Fine Gael seeing a role for them. A potential proposal involves establishing a commission to examine the future of Irish Water.

A fire broke out on the Sorrento ferry as it travelled towards Valencia, approximately 27km from Mallorca. The blaze began on a car deck on Tuesday afternoon and became uncontrollable, leading to a full evacuation. Passengers were moved to lifeboats and subsequently rescued by another ferry, the Puglia. At least three individuals were injured, one seriously, and airlifted to hospital. The cause of the fire remains unclear. The rescued passengers were being transported back to Palma de Mallorca. Authorities warned that the Sorrento might sink due to the damage sustained. The ferry, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, sent distress signals at 13:50 local time.
Following the general election, which had record registration (46.8

Lawrence Phillips, 40, a former star football player at the University of Nebraska and later in the NFL for the Rams, Dolphins, and 49ers until 1999, is believed by officials to have killed himself in prison on Wednesday. His career was marked by trouble on and off the field, and he continued to face legal issues after leaving the NFL. Phillips was serving a prison sentence of over 30 years for convictions including assault. He had been placed in a cell alone after being accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward. The day before his death, a judge had determined there was sufficient evidence to proceed with a trial against Phillips for Soward's death. His former coach, Tom Osborne, noted Phillips had intelligence and good qualities but struggled with anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram mascot for the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for "good behaviour" by Brigadier Andrew Williams at an event in Chester marking the regiment's eighth anniversary. Officially classed as a soldier, he is the 30th mascot ram in a lineage dating back to the mid-19th Century. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014, has his own army number, gets paid for rations, and takes holidays during mating season. He has also participated in events like switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time. The match was notable for Liverpool coming back from being 2-0 down early on, and later needing three goals in the final 33 minutes after falling behind 3-1. Manager Jurgen Klopp, facing his former club, invoked the spirit of Liverpool's 2005 Istanbul comeback and emphasized turning "doubters into believers," a theme central to the victory. Goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, and Mamadou Sakho preceded Lovren's winner. The intense Anfield atmosphere, fueled by Klopp and the fans, was credited with unsettling Dortmund. The win advances Liverpool to the Europa League semi-finals, offering a potential path back to the Champions League. The passage highlights Klopp's significant impact on the team's identity and

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee, Mr. Davis stated the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland updated on negotiations and proposed monthly meetings for information sharing, calling the meeting constructive. Mr. Russell, representing Scotland, acknowledged the engagement but criticized the lack of transparency from the UK government regarding its strategic intentions, particularly concerning the single market, which he deemed essential for Scotland's economy. Separately, the UK government hopes to overturn a High Court judgment on triggering Article 50 in the Supreme Court, while the Scottish government intends to oppose this appeal, seeking to have its Lord Advocate heard in the case.

Shutter Speed, the unbeaten 4-7 favourite trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. This marked a fifth Musidora win for both Gosden and Dettori. Dettori noted the ground was very soft and hard work for her, but she is considered "top drawer" and will be better on better ground. Shutter Speed will now go to Chantilly for the French Oaks over a mile and a quarter, rather than the Epsom Oaks, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are contenders. Gosden is pleased to have a month to prepare her. Separately, Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Gosden is also concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the upcoming Dante Stakes and will walk the course before deciding if he runs in the Derby trial, noting the short 16-day gap to the Derby.

Braintree ("The Iron") are currently sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off spots. Manager Cowley commented on a recent game against Barrow, noting the difficulty of conceding early after a long journey, but felt his team "asked a lot of questions". The loss extended Braintree's losing run to three games, while Barrow's unbeaten streak reached nine. Despite this, Cowley remains positive, calling their season so far "remarkable" and acknowledging the challenge for his part-time team, stating they will embrace and enjoy it.

From April 2015, responsibility for most planning decisions in Northern Ireland will transfer from the Planning Service agency to local councils, putting elected politicians in charge instead of planning officials. Michael Corr of PLACE views this optimistically as a "huge opportunity" for local development, suggesting voters will choose politicians skilled in planning. However, concerns exist, referencing historical discrimination by councils in the 1960s. Friends of the Earth warns of potential favouritism due to close relationships between developers and political parties, stressing the need for a rigorously enforced code of conduct and transparency. This increased power also fuels calls for greater transparency regarding political donations, although some politicians oppose this, citing donor security or the irrelevance of current donation limits. The Northern Ireland Secretary holds the authority to decide on increasing donation transparency.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times in NiddryView, Winchburgh, leading to the amputation of her left back leg. Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured on Friday 14 March and took her to the Scottish SPCA. The SPCA described the cat as "incredibly lucky" to survive and called the incident "alarming," using it to advocate for the urgent implementation of airgun licensing by the Scottish government. This follows a consultation last year where 87% of respondents opposed such licensing plans, which would require owners to demonstrate a legitimate reason for possessing an airgun. The SPCA is appealing for information about the shooting.

Christian Benteke has signed for Liverpool from Aston Villa on a "long-term contract", becoming the club's second most expensive signing after they triggered his release clause. The 24-year-old Belgian international scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa and joins Liverpool following their sale of Raheem Sterling and struggles for goals last season. Benteke stated he joined Liverpool to win trophies and be part of the manager's project. He is one of several attacking signings, including Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino, aimed at reviving Liverpool's attack. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge both believe Benteke will succeed at Anfield.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that while tablet use is widespread (in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools) and growing rapidly, there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using them. Researchers, led by Barbie Clarke, could not isolate technology's impact on attainment, although head teachers reported positive effects like increased motivation and family involvement when devices are taken home. The study noted young people's immersion in technology, with many taking devices to bed for social media. A separate study suggested touch-screens help boys and poorer pupils learn to read. A head teacher advocated for tablets, stating they empower pupils and align schools with the modern world, despite benefits being hard to quantify in league tables.

The "Growing Up in the City" exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs depicting children's lives in the city over more than 100 years, from the 1880s to the 1990s. The images offer a social history, showing how childhood, play, work, and special occasions have changed. Examples include an 1887 photo of wealthy children in fancy dress and a c. 1900 portrait of a young maid. Curator Kay Jones selected the images from National Museums Liverpool's collections to portray both the positive and negative experiences of childhood. The exhibition is open until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has cancelled his contract with Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals, the Gulls. Anderson is an ex-Aldershot and Exeter player. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, also joins the Gulls, having been recommended by Micky Adams. Keating previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, and his move is subject to international clearance. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a "leader-type" and Keating as "young" and "hungry". The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone.

Bolivia has enacted a new law permitting 12-year-olds to work with parental authorisation. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera stated this reflects the needs of Bolivia, one of South America's poorest countries, and aims to balance reality with law and international treaties. The law also sets harsher punishments for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. Signed by Mr. Garcia in President Evo Morales's absence, the government hopes it will help eradicate extreme poverty. Over 500,000 children already work in Bolivia according to Unicef. The International Labour Organisation (ILO), which sets minimum working ages (generally 15, or 14 for developing countries), is studying the legislation to see if it breaches international regulations. Mr. Garcia argued that a law strictly adhering to international conventions would be unenforceable

Rosie O'Donnell, 50, experienced a heart attack, describing herself as "lucky to be here". After feeling symptoms like chest ache, nausea, and feverishness following helping a woman, she looked up "women's heart attack symptoms" online and took aspirin, but did not call 911. A cardiologist visit the next day revealed a 99% blocked artery, identified as a "widow maker", which required a stent. O'Donnell wrote about the experience on her blog and urged women to know the symptoms, listen to their intuition, and call 911.

Che Labastide-Wellington was stabbed in an alleyway near Belvedere Way, Kenton, around 00:30 GMT after attending a party nearby on Saturday evening, and died about an hour later. Police believe he was targeted in this later scuffle, separate from an earlier altercation where youths tried to gain entry to the party. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and hospitalized in stable condition. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, while two boys (15 and 16) were arrested on the same suspicion and bailed. A 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

Denmark implemented a new approach to reorganise patient diagnosis by GPs and specialists, prompted by poor cancer survival statistics and long waiting times, especially for non-obvious cases. A Welsh team visited Aarhus, Denmark, to study this model. The Danish system introduced three routes: 1) Fast-track diagnosis for patients with "alarm" symptoms, with strict time targets and a 30-day investigation requirement for all GP referrals. 2) Diagnosis centres for patients with vague or undiagnosed symptoms, offering quick tests and scans to determine the cause, reducing "ping pong" between GPs and specialists. 3) "Yes-no" centres for patients with minor symptoms, providing rapid tests or scans to quickly rule out or detect serious conditions like cancer, significantly reducing potential delays. This reorganisation, achieved within existing resources, has led to better collaboration between GPs and specialists and improved cancer survival rates in Denmark, closing the gap with neighbouring countries. Wales is considering lessons from this approach due to similarities in their

Following the UK government's decision to disband the OFT, Powys council won a competitive bid to deliver a service in its place, receiving £170,000 a year. This new role involves issuing warning and banning orders against estate agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws. While people will still complain to their local authority trading standards, who can prosecute, cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. James Munro will lead the new Powys team and hopes this will lead to more contracts for the council in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan, based on a Nuffield Trust review, to reshape the NHS workforce by training staff like nurses and pharmacists to perform extra tasks traditionally done by doctors and GPs. The review found examples of this already happening and suggested it could help cover doctor shortages and address the changing nature of care, focusing more on long-term conditions. The report noted that doctors make up only about one-tenth of the workforce and that funding would be needed for training. While supporters like NHS Employers and the report's author see opportunities for improved patient care and staff roles, unions and the British Medical Association warned against using this as a cheap or quick fix for staff shortages, stressed the importance of doctor training and expertise, and raised concerns about the lack of funding for training.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road (A36) in Bath at Rackfield Place following a crash at 03:00 GMT. The closure, which lasted until 14:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays, particularly during rush hour. Investigations into the collision are underway. First bus services were affected, with the company expecting a return to full service by the evening commute and thanking the public and staff for their support and efforts.
Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon could kill 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually, based on the "best available

DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). This body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities across government and private sectors, benefiting an industry responsible for almost 100,000 jobs. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, citing the need for better coordination and the sector's role in export-led growth, but noted potential implications for other organisations and planned discussions with AFSB.

On Saturday afternoon, the public is invited to plant thousands of new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. Organised by the Woodland Trust, this is part of a UK-wide project creating four new woods to commemorate the millions who died in WW1, using the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." The specific goal at Brackfield Wood is to plant 40,000 native trees, honouring the estimated 40,000 Irish casualties of the conflict. The trust aims for the wood to become a place

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate for the book "Someone Else's Skin". The book, featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and dealing with domestic violence and honour crime, was praised by judges Alison Graham and Ann Cleeves for being powerful, finely written, and well-plotted. At the same event, US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career creating the detective VI Warshawski. Paretsky was noted for creating a "game changer" strong female protagonist and founding Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers. The awards were presented at the start of the Harrogate crime writing festival.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, will rejoin Worcestershire Rapids after the ICC Trophy in June. He previously played for the county in 2016 but broke his finger in his second game. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes stated there is "unfinished business" with Santner, whose injury was a "massive blow" to their qualifying hopes last summer. Santner expressed enjoyment of his previous time at Worcester and hopes to make an impact with bat and ball upon his return. Worcestershire also signed Australian bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring was killed by a speeding car with stolen licence plates in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was absent, having returned to a restaurant. A UK coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, satisfied beyond reasonable doubt based on overwhelming circumstantial evidence. Pring's family and a close friend believe he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run orchestrated by Ziuzina for financial gain. Ziuzina, who married Pring quickly after meeting online, attempted to claim his assets, sold his property, moved funds, and was allegedly having an affair. She did not attend the inquest despite efforts to compel her. A Ukrainian murder inquiry was reopened in 2011 but is reportedly not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, from Merseyside, urgently requires experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital in America, as treatment options in the UK are unavailable following a relapse and a failed previous transplant. An anonymous donor has paid for the treatment, specifically requesting to cover Charlie's costs. His parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns, expressed being overwhelmed and extremely grateful for this generosity, which was confirmed via an email from the hospital. Charlie now has financial clearance, and the treatment will commence as soon as possible, with the date expected to be confirmed next week.

Following the theft of celebrity photos from iCloud, likely using third-party software, Apple extended its two-step verification system to cover iCloud backups. This security measure, which requires a code sent to a trusted device in addition to the password when logging in from a new device, aims to block tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, previously used to download backups even if two-step verification was enabled

A deal is being discussed for Wright to potentially buy 20% of Billericay and become a club director, although the "finer points" are yet to be released, according to Dan Groves. Billericay currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright, who previously played non-league football for clubs like Lewes and Crawley Town and was a runner-up on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, would be joining a club recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who stated he was comfortable investing £10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky at the start of March.

Mr Ashley has been asked to give evidence to the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee regarding the treatment of workers at his company's warehouse, following a BBC investigation. The committee, chaired by Iain Wright MP, insists on a public meeting at Westminster, despite Mr Ashley inviting them to the company's base. Mr Ashley has been offered alternative dates but has not accepted them or agreed in principle to attend. He has until 21 March to respond, and failure to agree to attend could lead to the committee taking further action, potentially including seeking support from the House of Commons for a complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has not commented to the BBC but previously pledged a review of worker rights.

Colleagues of a murdered Russian opposition politician, led by Ilya Yashin, completed his report titled "Putin. War." Based largely on previously published facts since the 2014 Crimea annexation and eastern Ukraine conflict, the report argues President Vladimir Putin is waging war for personal ends, costing an estimated 53bn roubles. Despite Russia's denials and claims that Russians fighting are "volunteers," the report presents evidence, including soldier testimony, suggesting Russian army units directed by generals were decisive

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem determined he died from head injuries. Subsequently, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, complained that he did not see the Article 50 letter before it was published and was not invited to contribute to its drafting, calling the process unacceptable and disrespectful to devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered that discussions about the letter's contents had occurred over months and the UK government acts in the interest of the whole UK. Prime Minister Theresa May's letter to Donald Tusk stated there would be consultation on which returning powers should be devolved, with an expectation of a significant increase in decision-making power for devolved administrations like Wales. However, it remains unclear which specific powers will be devolved and whether funding will accompany them, with Carwyn Jones expressing concern about the lack of money after 2020. More details might be revealed in a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, involving attacks on PSNI officers who were carrying out their duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed being appalled by the attacks on officers and the community. A PSNI Facebook post appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr. Charney, the company's founder, was ousted last year following employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. In a court filing responding to Mr. Charney's defamation lawsuit, the board presented evidence including illicit emails and racial taunts, stating he violated sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies and is not expected to return. The board believes the risks associated with him would prevent any company from hiring him. Mr. Charney's lawyer claims the statements are false and an extortion attempt. The company has also obtained a restraining order against Mr. Charney.

Great Britain (GB) will play Greece in a basketball game at the Copper Box in London, which will be covered on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app from 17:30-19:30 BST. This is GB's only home game before FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which starts in early September in Turkey. Greece previously defeated GB 92-64 in Patras, but three Greek players from that match will be absent for the London game, offering GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box and sees the game as vital preparation for EuroBasket. Following this

The passage recounts the narrator's experience reporting on the launch of the first iPhone. Initially facing difficulty obtaining the device, the narrator managed to borrow one from Apple's Phil Schiller for a news piece. This coverage drew criticism for giving undue prominence to a product launch, which the narrator defended by comparing the iPhone's potential impact to the Model T Ford – a comparison initially regretted but later seen as apt. The passage describes the iPhone as the key transformative technology of the last decade, putting powerful computers into billions of hands and disrupting industries like photography, making it easier to capture and instantly share images. It credits Steve Jobs' genius in creating an attractive user interface as crucial to encouraging users to do more than just talk and text. Despite initial skepticism, the narrator now views the iPhone launch as a historic moment that began the mobile connected era.

Five cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting a toxic substance confirmed by tests to be antifreeze. The most recent death was a seven-month-old cat named Meereen on Monday. Her owner found her shivering and foaming at the mouth before she died three days after being taken to the vets. The RSPCA stated it is unclear if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is appealing for residents to store chemicals like antifreeze safely and clean up any spills, particularly as it is the time of year people use it in cars.

Despite the Syriza government preparing to implement more austerity and liberalisation measures mandated by creditors for an €86bn third bailout—policies it previously opposed—there are no street protests in Athens. Tourism is increasing significantly, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals. The lack of protest may be temporary, pending details of the deal, or due to Syriza adopting a "There Is No Alternative" (TINA) stance following Greece's near-death economic experience in July, which included bank closures. Despite failing to end fiscal austerity and causing monetary austerity through continued bank restrictions, Prime Minister Tsipras remains popular. Greece faces a severe economic squeeze with VAT increases, pension cuts, and lack of credit impacting businesses. The passage concludes that for the bailout to lead to recovery, creditors, especially Berlin, must offer substantial debt forgiveness rather than focusing solely on Athens' capitulation.

Ross Kemp is returning briefly to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Dame Barbara Windsor's final episodes. Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, recently reappeared to reveal her cancer had returned and will be killed off in scenes airing in the spring. Kemp stated he couldn't turn down the return, citing his close friendship with Windsor and the storyline involving the Mitchell brothers reuniting with their mother for the last time. The show's executive producer highlighted the significance of Grant returning to say goodbye to Peggy and reuniting with his brother Phil during this time.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles before fatally attacking her. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, immediately suspected Dhillon when police informed them of her death. Dhillon, who was obsessed with Alice, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Alice's mother expressed guilt for having reassured her daughter despite warnings. The parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and want Alice remembered for her vibrant personality.

French firm EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point nuclear project in Somerset, with one-third of the cost provided by Chinese investors. However, hours after EDF's approval, the UK government, citing Business Secretary Greg Clark, announced it would "consider carefully" and launched a further review, delaying the final decision. This unexpected move surprised EDF executives, halted investment momentum

A newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with. Family lawyers express concern that although naming this third party is not obligatory according to the Ministry of Justice and accompanying guidance, the form's direct question encourages it. Lawyers like Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin state that naming the third party increases conflict, complexity, potential delays, and costs, as that person then becomes part of the court case. While the Ministry of Justice highlights there is "no obligation" and the form aims to be user-friendly, lawyers fear applicants, especially those without legal advice, will feel compelled to fill in the box or ignore the guidance. Many clients initially want to name the third party, but lawyers advise against it, noting judges view it negatively. Adultery accounted for just over 12,000 of the 100,000 divorces in England and Wales in 2015.

There is a perceived conflict between ministerial emphasis on environmental goals and the needs of commercial forestry for timber production, particularly as Britain is a major wood importer. Confor, representing the industry, warns that 40,000 acres of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and require replanting. The Welsh forestry industry is valued at over £450m annually, with woodland managed by both Natural Resources Wales and private companies. While ministers encourage investment and the Welsh government seeks a balance between environmental, economic

A boy was badly injured after being struck on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge at approximately 16:40. Emergency crews attended the scene, and the boy was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow. His condition is believed to be serious.

Defence Attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to British veterans of the Arctic Convoys, including Able Seaman Charles Lewis, who felt honoured. The Foreign Office initially blocked the awards due to rules on foreign medals but later made an exception. The Russian Embassy highlighted the convoys' crucial role in supplying the Soviet Union to defeat Germany during WWII, calling it a material expression of the wartime alliance. The Arctic Convoys involved perilous journeys from Britain to northern Russia, facing German attacks and severe weather, resulting in heavy losses; Churchill reportedly called it the "worst journey on earth". The British government created the Arctic Star medal in 2012, and President Putin presented the first Ushakov medals in London in June 2013. The Ushakov medal recognizes sailors who displayed courage defending Russia or its interests.

The passage discusses accusations of hypocrisy leveled against comedian Russell Brand, who campaigns for economic and political change for the poor while living in a luxury home. Examples include a newspaper headline calling him a "hypocrite" and a confrontation with a TV reporter about his own rent while protesting housing issues, during which he called the journalist "a snide". Brand acknowledges the charge and his wealth, stating he needs personal change and that fame and fortune are not the answer. However, he argues that individual wealth sharing is futile without systemic change and that critics use the hypocrisy accusation to avoid addressing the real problem of economic inequality. He accepts his personal flaws but insists they don't negate the facts about economic disparity and ecological disaster, suggesting the hypocrisy issue can be addressed incrementally.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, significantly accelerated the mapping of the human genome through a competitive approach, which drew criticism from the scientific community. His experience in Vietnam instilled a sense of urgency. After working at the NIH

Based on a survey of about 1,000 parents in England, researchers found that four out of five children eating school lunches had tried new foods at school. Half of the parents surveyed reported their children asking for foods eaten at school to be cooked at home. The research, commissioned by England's School Food Trust, identified carrots, sweetcorn, and peas as popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less popular. Experts suggest school meals, which now meet strict nutritional guidelines and offer more variety, help children try new foods, partly due to peer pressure

Morata, 23, is playing for Spain at Euro 2016. He joined Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid, who retained a buy-back option reported to be up to 30m euros (£23m). Morata, previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, has scored three times for Spain in the tournament. During his two years at Juventus, he scored 27 goals, won two Serie A titles, two Coppa Italias, and played in the 2015 Champions League final, scoring in the defeat. He also appeared as a substitute in Real Madrid's 2014 Champions League final win. Morata came through Real's ranks, debuting at 18 and scoring 10 goals for them.

Wilson, 30, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He has been without a team since being released in May. This was his second spell at Forest, where he made 51 appearances, having previously spent four seasons there before joining Celtic. Wilson has also had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

British supermarket giant Tesco is disposing of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. Fresh & Easy, operating 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since its 2007 opening. As part of the deal, Tesco will loan the new business £80m, and about 4,000 of the 5,000 employees will transfer. It is understood the remaining 50 shops will close. The disposal will cost Tesco £150m, partly comprising the loan which might be repaid. Tesco retains the option to buy a stake if Yucaipa makes the business profitable. Tesco described this as an "orderly and efficient exit from the US market".

He initially experienced racial abuse but overcame it. After briefly considering representing France, he is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. He explained this to BBC Sport's Nick Hope. The passage also mentions a guide on getting into martial arts.

Research presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting indicates a significant reduction in the ice fields of the French Alps. Between the late 1960s/early 1970s and the late 2000s, the glacier-covered area decreased from approximately 375 sq km to about 275 sq km, representing an average loss of 26% over 40 years. This new inventory, compiled by Marie Gardent and colleagues using maps, satellite imagery, aerial photos, and manual verification, assessed roughly 600 glaciers. The study found that glacier retreat has accelerated since the mid-1980s and is more pronounced in the southern sectors (like Ecrins and Belledonne) compared to the northern Mont Blanc Massif, attributed to lower elevations and different climatic conditions in the south. These findings mirror glacier retreat observed in other Alpine regions.

The Scottish women's football team has won all five qualifiers and faces a crucial match against Iceland, who are also unbeaten. Victory for Scotland would almost secure their place in the upcoming finals in the Netherlands. Player Lisa Evans expresses determination to qualify after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the World Cup. The two matches between Scotland and Iceland are likely to decide the group winner, though Scotland is well-positioned to qualify even as a runner-up. Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, notes Iceland are a tough opponent but beatable, and hopes for strong home support. Many Scottish players, including Evans and BBC Women's Footballer of the Year Kim Little, play professionally outside Scotland. Evans believes playing in top leagues like the German Bundesliga, where she recently won the title with Bayern, benefits the national team by

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England following a complaint from a woman in south London alleging online harassment over a two-year period. He was released on bail until mid-September pending further inquiries. Mr. Campbell stated the allegation relates entirely to some tweets, which he insists were not threatening and remain publicly visible. He accused the media of using "innuendo" to encourage "speculations". The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating the allegation made by a woman in her 30s. Campbell, who runs the Wings Over Scotland blog, is a campaigner for Scottish independence.

Peta is requesting that the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness be replaced with an animal-friendly version, suggesting a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice". Peta argues the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty associated with fishing. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, featuring the slogan "Skegness is so bracing", was commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway to promote tourism. Skegness Mayor Carl Macey acknowledged the suggestion would go before the council but expressed doubt about support for replacing the mascot, stating it is widely loved, seen as happy and friendly, and does not portray cruelty.

In a rugby match, Georgia initially led with an early try by Vasil Lobzhanidze. However, Scotland quickly took control before half-time with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg, dominating possession. Hamish Watson scored for Scotland early in the second half. Georgia responded with a second try for Lobzhanidze resulting from a powerful scrum, which caused Scotland problems and led to a yellow card for Moray Low. Stuart Hogg scored his second try, Scotland's sixth, near the end of the match following a break initiated by debutant Ali Price. Scotland's coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's first-half performance, pragmatic approach, and overall improvement, highlighting Greig Laidlaw's leadership. The passage also includes the full team lists for both Scotland and Georgia.

Widnes secured a victory over Castleford, leading 14-6 at half-time thanks to tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, with Paddy Flynn scoring for Castleford against his parent club. Widnes extended their lead to 38-12 in the second half with further tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. Despite a late surge from Castleford with tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn completing his hat-trick, Widnes held on for the win. This marked Castleford's fourth consecutive home league defeat. The result moved Widnes to seventh place, while Castleford remained sixth. Larne Patrick has recently signed a three-year deal to move from Huddersfield.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, has been released from the US facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after being held since 2002. A US review panel concluded in July that he was no longer a "continuing significant threat". Arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies,

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major World War One battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces (the Gallipoli landings), was marked in London with several events. Thousands attended a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, up to 400 people participated in a parade leading to a wreath-laying ceremony at the Cenotaph, and a service was held at Westminster Abbey. The first London commemoration occurred in 1916. Today, these services are significant for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians honouring war sacrifices. Alexander Downer, Australian high commissioner, spoke at the dawn service reflecting on the Gallipoli landings. Veterans, service personnel, and families took part in the parade watched by crowds, and the Cenotaph ceremony included prayers and national anthems. The Gallipoli campaign itself was an eight-month, bloody WWI operation against the Ottoman empire.

Clarkson, aged 30, has joined St Mirren from Premiership Well and could make his debut against Alloa in the Championship on Saturday. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has mainly been a substitute this term, but states he is fit and ready, having played U20s games and trained hard. Capped twice for Scotland in 2008 with one international goal, Clarkson has almost 400 senior club appearances, with previous teams including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren are currently eighth in the Championship, and Clarkson aims to help the team win games and move up the table.

A turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Following productive talks, Unite regional officer Steve Harley received guarantees that all current agreements, including the existing workers' pension scheme (which replaced a final salary scheme closed in 2004), will be honoured by the new ownership. Boparan's private office confirmed this continuation. The new owner aims to restore the business to profitability through greater investment, cost savings, and utilising spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

At a council scrutiny meeting regarding problems with a new vessel (chain ferry), Council leader Dave Stewart announced the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July due to the issues and that a review had been ordered. He described the ferry's start as "frustrating and disappointing". Since its May launch, the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended due to training issues, and damaged cars. A local shopkeeper, Angie Booth, expressed concerns about business survival due to lost trade and asked about compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward confirmed compensation was being discussed, referred to the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems (like rectified electrical issues), mentioned ramp extensions were ordered to address car damage, and stated grounding issues related to seamanship had been resolved.

A House of Lords report examines the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit, an industry that largely supported leaving the EU due to dislike of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The report warns that while fishing is a small part of the UK GDP, its communities must not be marginalised in negotiations. Key complexities include shared fish stocks with the EU, the UK's reliance on exporting fish to the EU, and importing fish consumed domestically. Continued access to the EU market may require allowing EU boats access to UK waters. The report suggests retaining science-based quotas and international cooperation, but notes the potential for fragmented UK fisheries management. Despite these concerns, many in the industry remain optimistic about Brexit offering control and fairer shares, while the government aims for maximum trade freedom and a review of fisheries management.

A fire occurred on 2 March at a site on Duncan Street, causing travel disruption. Following the blaze, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste. The fire service stated the site operator, Asset and Land Group, was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, despite the fire service having raised concerns to the EA in February about the potential impact of a fire. After joint visits, the EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed. The company must remove all waste from the site. The cause of the fire is undetermined.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated Syria is "doing its best" to meet the chemical weapons destruction timetable, despite missing a deadline to hand over its stockpile. He cited attacks on shipments by "terrorist groups" and the ongoing war as reasons for delays. The US expressed concern about the slow progress (only about 4% removed) and condemned the alleged use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which Mekdad called "unacceptable," denying that civilians were targeted. Activist groups reported hundreds killed in Aleppo from barrel bombs. Conflicting reports emerged about Aleppo's central prison, with rebels claiming to have seized it and freed detainees, while the Syrian government denied this, stating the attack was thwarted. Russia suggested a March

England secured a decisive victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series. Described as a "hammering" and England's second biggest win over Pakistan by runs, the match saw England

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners, their friends, families, care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. This evidence will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies, highlighting good care and showing the impact of poor care. The review will examine factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but expressed disappointment that no provider expert is included on the main advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, 39, who has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, is replacing Neil Cooper at Aberdeen (Pittodrie). Sheerin is a former Dons midfielder and was chosen by Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes after a comprehensive process. Arbroath chairman John Christison understood Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin previously played for several Scottish clubs, Ö

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams are taking temporary charge of Swansea for the upcoming match. The club seeks a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement being the first choice. Curtis expressed concerns about potential relegation, noting the difficulty of promotion from the Championship and questioning if Swansea could retain top players if relegated, unlike clubs like Newcastle. He reflected on Swansea's rise from near bankruptcy to the Premier League in 2011 and their subsequent reputation, but feels the club has lost its "Swansea Way" since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 due to frequent management changes and inadequate player replacements. Despite this, Curtis believes the current squad can stay up and informs new players about the club's history to emphasize the importance of avoiding relegation for the club and the area.

The Briton, Storey, won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, who is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) across swimming and cycling from six Paralympics, expressed relief at the win. She has now won 21 world titles across both sports. Storey began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005. She is targeting further success at the Rio de Janeiro Paralympics next year and could win a 17th title in Saturday's road race.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to financial issues. Despite surviving relegation on the final day of the season (sending Chester down), the club failed to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle, players, staff, and other clubs. The Conference extended the payment deadline three times, ultimately setting it for 12 June. Following a takeover by Tommy Agombar on 3 June, the club still failed to meet the deadline and was expelled on 10 June. Consequently, Chester has been reinstated into the Conference Premier. Hereford's financial decline, exacerbated by falling attendances since their 2012 Football League relegation, also included over £70,0

The 30-year-old former Manchester City player, Milner, earned 61 caps for England following his senior debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46, starting in 2004. His sole international goal was scored during England's 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. He referred to the decision reached as "common sense" and extended well wishes to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after an illness. He was a conductor known as one of the most influential figures in the early-music movement. In 1973, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), which he directed for about 30 years, leading it across six continents and making over 200 recordings, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a famous version of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood also held positions as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and academic roles at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. His funeral will be private, with a memorial

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream schooling in June as he was not coping. His parents requested a place at a special school but were informed in September that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full, with no timeframe for a place becoming available. This situation has left the boy feeling isolated, and his mother had to give up her job to care for him. Recently, an extra classroom assistant was employed at a local special school, offering hope that the boy might secure a place soon. However, his mother worries about the overall capacity issues within the special needs school system affecting other families. The Education Authority declined to comment on the individual case, citing privacy, but stated they are reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland for 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue. Newport County has a lease to use the ground until 2023, with primacy of fixtures if they stay in the Football League, and expects this contract to be honoured. A shareholder vote on the WRU takeover is scheduled for May 9th. Newport RFC's chairman confirmed that both County and Newport Squash Club are

The passage describes the experiences of a man from Sierra Leone, a country recently declared free of a virus (Ebola) that killed nearly 4,000 people there. Kidnapped at 15 by RUF rebels during the civil war, he was forced into violence and drug use before escaping. After being jailed, he met preacher Richard Cole, founder of the Lifeline Nehemiah project, who encouraged him towards education and rebuilding the nation. During the 2014 Ebola

Approximately 80,000 items in the Wedgwood collection, including art, ceramics, and documents, were at risk of being auctioned to cover pension debts inherited after Waterford Wedgwood plc collapsed in 2009. The museum itself went into administration in 2010, and a 2011 court ruling permitted the sale. However, a public fundraising campaign launched in September and led by The Art Fund successfully reached its target within a month. Consequently, the collection was saved from being sold off. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan it back to the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, allowing it to remain on display. The collection is considered important for Staffordshire and significant for Britain's cultural history.

A deal is being discussed for Wright to potentially buy 20% of Billericay and become a club director, although the "finer points" are not yet released. Billericay, recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin who is comfortable investing £10,000 a week, is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright is a former non-league footballer and was runner-up on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011. The club also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes when Jamille Matt scored from a Nathan Delfouneso chip. Goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made a sensational save for Blackpool soon after, but Colchester equalised from the resulting corner through Kurtis Guthrie. Slocombe made another brilliant save just before half-time, and Guthrie hit the bar for Colchester. Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a clear chance to win the game 15 minutes from the end. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card for a bad tackle in injury time. The match ended Blackpool 1, Colchester United 1.

The disused Fawley power station chimney is set to become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard, serving as the centrepiece for a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside. The development plans include a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The original oil-fired power station operated from 1971 to 2013, powered one million homes, and the site was sold to the developers in 2016. An application for outline planning permission is due later this year, with building potentially starting in 2018.

Chris Latham won Great Britain's second medal at the Hong Kong championships, securing bronze in the men's scratch race behind Poland's Adrian Teklinski (gold) and Germany's Lucass Liss (silver). This followed Elinor Barker's silver

Ross Kemp is making a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Dame Barbara Windsor's final episodes. Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, recently reappeared to reveal her cancer had returned and will be killed off in scenes airing in the spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and 2005-2006, stated he felt it was right for the Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil, to reunite with their mother for the last time. His return will see the brothers face losing their mother. Grant Mitchell is described as one of the soap's most memorable characters and an "EastEnders legend".

Sadio Mane scored two goals in 138 seconds, leading to a defeat for second-placed Spurs at Anfield. Spurs manager Pochettino criticized his team's performance, stating they showed a "lack of desire" and were "not ready to fight for the Premier League" if they played like that, adding they could not "cope with the pressure". He expressed concern that Chelsea could extend their lead to 12 points. The passage notes Spurs' poor away record, with only two wins since September 24 and just one win in their last 17 away meetings against top-six sides. Pundit Danny Murphy expressed surprise at Spurs'

In Saturday's elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 declared governorships, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. This follows the PDP's loss in the presidential election the previous month, where APC leader Muhammadu Buhari defeated President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and Adamawa, but held onto Rivers State and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC made historic gains, winning most northern states and Lagos, but failed to win any oil-producing states. The PDP's decline is attributed to defections, corruption allegations, perceived failure against the Boko Haram insurgency, and a desire for change after 16 years in power. While violence marred elections in some areas,

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) can use an app to access online information, including videos and band interviews, triggered from items like signs and posters via augmented reality. The festival takes place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July, featuring acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. According to director Caroline Maclennan, this feature aims to enhance visitor enjoyment and allow people globally to interact with the festival, access updated information and interviews, buy tickets, and experience its atmosphere.

Following Ofsted inspections related to the "Trojan Horse" allegations, Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate, will have their funding agreements terminated, potentially removing the Park View Educational Trust from running them. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns, including segregation and curriculum balance, are addressed by a deadline. Ofsted reports cited inadequate safeguarding against extremism and a "culture of fear," with one head teacher describing feeling undermined by parents. The Park View trust plans to legally challenge the Ofsted report, while some parents have criticized the findings as biased.

Vincent Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, is charged with gross negligence manslaughter, which she denies. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court alleges that her failure to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test and refer him for further investigation constitutes conduct so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal". They claim this failure led to Vinnie's preventable death from a build-up of fluid in his brain. The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse with another man, whom he found via an adult website, between September 2013 and September 2014, and filming them. He was also convicted of intentionally causing the victim's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving abusively on Christmas Day 2014, having sent a sexually explicit clip to the sister. Despite denying the charges, Weatherhogg was convicted after a trial at Dundee Sheriff Court. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers, and he was placed on the sex offenders register. The judge noted the sentence must reflect "society's abhorrence," and Weatherhogg was assessed as a "moderate risk" of sexual re-offending.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Afghanistan defeated Ireland by reaching 171-4 with two overs to spare, chasing Ireland's total of 165-5. Key scores for Ireland came from Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 no), and captain William Porterfield (39), while Paul Stirling was out for a duck. For Afghanistan, Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) led the chase, with Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai (27) putting on an opening stand of 51. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23. Porterfield felt Ireland were about 15 runs short and didn't execute well with the ball. Ireland paceman Boyd Rankin missed the game with a back problem but is expected back for the ODIs starting 15 March. The teams play the second T20 on Friday at the same venue.

Barcelona signed Neymar for an initial fee of £48.6m, with £34m going to his parents, though the total cost including wages and fees is estimated at £106.8m. Following allegations that the actual cost was higher than the initially stated €57m (£48.6m) and accusations of misappropriated money, club president Sandro Rosell resigned, although he denies wrongdoing. A judge ruled there was sufficient evidence to investigate Barcelona for potential tax crimes related to the transfer. While denying any offence or tax crime, Barcelona made a "complimentary" tax payment of €13.55m to cover potential interpretations and defend their reputation, maintaining their original payments were fiscally compliant. It is unconfirmed if the case will be dropped following this payment.

David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found murdered on a Koh Tao beach on 15 September. Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are being held by Thai police as suspects, alleged to have confessed and charged with conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, potentially facing the death penalty. UK Metropolitan Police detectives visited Thailand to review the investigation, have completed their work as far as possible, and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the victims' families. The UK Foreign Office previously expressed concerns about the Thai investigation regarding DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of the suspects. Post-mortem examinations found Mr Miller died from drowning and a head blow, while Miss Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police stated DNA found on Ms Witheridge matched samples from the suspects.

Scotland's women's football team has won all five qualifiers to date and faces a crucial match against Iceland, who are also unbeaten. Victory for Scotland could virtually secure their place in the finals. Player Lisa Evans expresses the team's desperation to qualify after suffering play-off losses for Euro 2013 and the last World Cup, calling potential failure "heartbreak." Iceland is ranked similarly to Scotland, and the matches between them will likely decide the group winner, although Scotland is also well-positioned to qualify as one of the best runners-up.
