Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich and recently won the Bundesliga, believes the experience gained by Scottish players playing in top foreign leagues (like Germany, England, Sweden, and the USA) benefits the national team by bringing different skills and improving players.

Following the theft of celebrity photos from iCloud, potentially using third-party software, Apple has implemented two-step verification for its backup service to prevent infiltration. This security measure, which requires both a password and a code sent to a trusted device for access or purchases, remains an opt-in choice, although experts suggest it should be the default. Previously, even with two-step verification enabled on an account, backups could be accessed using tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple's changes now block this method and notify users via email when a backup download starts. Concerns remain about the difficulty of managing the 14-character recovery key needed if a trusted device is lost. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and improve password security awareness.

During the May European election campaign period (23 January to 22 May), UKIP, the winners, spent £2,956,737 (£0.68 per vote), while the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (£0.79 per vote). Labour came second, spending £1,027,339 (£0.26 per vote). The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) and lost all but one MEP. The Green Party spent £534,249 (£0.43 per vote). Including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087. All these parties, except Labour, spent more than in the 2009 campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has cancelled his contract with Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals Torquay United ("Gulls"). Anderson previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, also joins Torquay, recommended by Micky Adams. Keating has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, with his move pending international clearance. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader type and Keating as young and hungry. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed the cause was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". The BHA's acting chief veterinary officer stated such episodes are rare and can occur without underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), he showed no such symptoms on Saturday and had recovered from past incidents under monitoring. The report concluded he died from a haemorrhage rarely seen on racetracks. Many Clouds was a previous winner of the Gold Cup trial (2015) and the Hennessy Gold Cup (2014).

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became emotional during the farewell speeches of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, as they, along with Marwick and former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie, are standing down ahead of the 5 May election. In his valedictory address, Salmond reiterated his belief that Scotland was "diverse, not divided" and called for the parliament to assume greater responsibility, welcoming the Scotland Bill but stating it didn't fulfil referendum pledges. He concluded with "goodbye... for now". McNeil, an MSP since 1999, used his final speech to warn that Holyrood needed to learn from Westminster's committee system regarding accountability and scrutiny. Goldie also made a farewell speech, joking about Finance Secretary John Swinney.

An unnamed star will play Mrs Potts, previously voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animation. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the film, which begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios. The US cinema release date is set for 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decisions on whether to bring charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans were fatally injured. The decisions will be revealed to victims' relatives at a private meeting in Warrington at 11:00 BST by Sue Hemming, head of the CPS special crime and counter-terrorism division. This follows inquests last year which concluded the fans were unlawfully killed, and the referral of evidence files concerning 23 suspects to the CPS in January. These suspects relate to investigations into the causes of the disaster (Operation Resolve) and the subsequent conduct of South Yorkshire and West Midlands Police (IPCC probe). Margaret Aspinall, chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed hope for accountability after a long struggle, anticipating a day of mixed emotions for the families.

Chelmsford Prison has reported "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over its wall. A former inmate stated the prison is known for being "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A local resident witnessed packages being thrown over four times in two weeks and mentioned the prison is planning a meeting with residents about the issue. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged that staff work hard to stop contraband but stated more must be done, with the Justice Secretary looking into providing prisons with the necessary tools. New laws mean smugglers could face up to two years in jail. While the former inmate claimed drones were used, the Ministry of Justice said there was no evidence of this at the Chelmsford site.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial at Luton Crown Court, accused of causing serious injury by dangerous driving after striking Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady, with his VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School last December. Mrs Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Mr Wright accepts hitting her but denies the charge, stating he was blinded by the setting sun and does not remember if the traffic light was red. The prosecution alleges he failed to stop for a red light while Mrs Blackburn was escorting pedestrians. Mr Wright expressed deep remorse in court. The trial continues.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner studying veterinary medicine, will miss the Commonwealth Games in Australia due to a clash with her final year exams in May. Muir, who finished 4th in the 1500m and 6th in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships (setting a new outdoor personal best in the latter), expressed disappointment but emphasized the importance of her degree. She is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a "potential target" and believes she has "at least two, even three more Olympics" in her future.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in Dublin in December 2000 while walking home from a Christmas party. A search involving excavations has begun at a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, expected to last several weeks. This follows a review of the case initiated earlier this year, which involved enhancing CCTV footage from the night he went missing. The footage shows Deely talking to an unidentified man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where Deely worked. Gardaí believe this same man was later seen following Deely on Haddington Road and have renewed their appeal for him to come forward, as he has not yet been identified.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after significant injury time, defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3. This marks his first Grand Slam appearance since 2014 due to wrist operations. Del Potro, a former US Open champion, expressed feeling "alive" and will next play Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. In the same half of the draw, Nick Kyrgios beat Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7)

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON) due to complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea. However, Tunisia apologised, clarifying they criticised the referee choice rather than alleging corruption, and resolved the issue after a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Morocco was also able to enter the 2017 qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a Caf ban imposed when Morocco refused to host the 2015 AFCON due to Ebola fears; Cas also reduced Morocco's fine. Both nations are now participating in the 2017 qualifiers, with Tunisia in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

McLaren's current F1 performance is poor, with modest goals like fourth or third row grid positions, a significant decline from their past greatness which includes 182 wins and numerous championships. Despite having world champion Fernando Alonso, the team's slump, which began in 2013 with chassis issues, now primarily stems from problems with their Honda power unit, ironically a partner during their most dominant era (1988-1991). McLaren's history shows cycles of triumph and decline, including previous slumps, scandals (2007, 2009), and periods of success under Ron Dennis, who has returned to lead the team. Dennis and Alonso believe McLaren will recover, citing car improvements and faith in Honda's future engine development, aiming to eventually challenge Mercedes and win titles again. Currently, this recovery relies on

Following a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, police found people still present and till receipts showing alcohol served as late as 04:49 BST. License holder Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. A defence solicitor stated licensing laws in Dungiven "were not strictly adhered to". The judge, calling it "as bad a case as I have come across" and noting Ms O'Neill's "appalling record", ordered the bar closed for three months, fined Ms O'Neill £3,000, and fined Mr Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points with eight 3-pointers, as the Golden State Warriors defeated the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Klay Thompson added 26 points for the Warriors. LaMarcus Aldridge scored 27 points for the Trail Blazers.

In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic met YouTube star Bas van Velzen at Melwood, believing he was a competition winner seeking a free-kick masterclass. Van Velzen, actually a Dutch free-kick specialist, surprised the players by showcasing his own skills, which wowed the quartet. Van Velzen described the experience as amazing, especially meeting Balotelli, and enjoyed pretending he wasn't skilled before revealing his abilities. He also unveiled Balotelli's infamous slogan as a final surprise.

Carriers of the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, face a high risk of developing breast and ovarian cancer. A Canadian study found that for women diagnosed with breast cancer linked to the BRCA1 gene, having their ovaries removed (oophorectomy) reduced their risk of dying from breast cancer by 62% and from all causes by 65%. This survival benefit was not observed in women with the BRCA2 mutation. The protective effect for BRCA1 carriers was apparent immediately after diagnosis, lasted for 15 years, and was even greater (73% reduction in death) if the procedure was done within two years of diagnosis. Experts suggest oophorectomy should be discussed as a potential treatment option for BRCA1 carriers at the time of their breast cancer

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member, worked as an informant for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia. He was a valuable asset, aiding in undercover stings and the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. In exchange for his work, he was promised US citizenship but never received it. Now retired due to declining health, Toro is living in the US illegally, facing deportation, and fears he will be killed if sent back to Colombia. The DEA refused to help with his citizenship after he went public, leaving him in legal limbo without documentation or benefits.

The US body regulating internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., over its use of the new '.sucks' domain name. Vox Populi is charging high sums, around $2,000-$2,499 a year, primarily through resellers, to celebrities like Kevin Spacey and major companies such as YouTube, Bing, and Visa, who wish to secure their names under this domain to protect their reputations. ICANN, which initially approved the domain, is now questioning the practice after an advisory panel labeled it a "shakedown scheme." ICANN has contacted the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal, which could lead to breach of contract proceedings.

Kristopher Hicks suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving taxi driven by Michael Young in Bath five years ago. The driver, mistakenly believing Mr Hicks intended not to pay the fare, decided to drive him back to the taxi rank instead of his destination. Mr Hicks objected and jumped from the vehicle while it was moving at over 20mph. As a result, he sustained devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires constant care. A High Court judge ruled that the driver had unlawfully imprisoned Mr Hicks, making him liable for compensation. The final amount is yet to be determined but is expected to be around 50% of the requested sum, plus £250 for

Luke Rockhold is preparing to fight Lyoto Machida in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. Rockhold describes his strategy as being "the bull" to Machida's "matador," planning to pressure, cut off, and dominate his opponent, exploiting perceived weaknesses and utilizing his well-rounded skills. He respects Machida but is confident in his ability to win, believing Machida has limited paths to victory. Machida is also confident, believing he can win by applying his own style and strategy, and feels the winner deserves a title shot. He states he is well-prepared after an eight-week training camp. Both fighters are coming off recent wins.

Manuel Pellegrini has admitted disappointment in Yaya Toure's performances this season, as has Toure himself according to Pellegrini. Despite this and reports that Manchester City will listen to offers for the midfielder as part of a squad overhaul, Pellegrini vowed to support Toure until at least the end of the season. Goalkeeper Joe Hart stated that the players feel they have let the manager down and take responsibility for the team's poor form. City captain Vincent Kompany is out injured. Separately, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warned player Aaron Cresswell about moving to a big club like Manchester City (who are reportedly interested in him), citing the limited playing time of previous signings like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive living in the UK for over 20 years, will be allowed to remain in the country despite facing extradition to Italy. Although convicted in absentia in 1999 and sentenced to seven years for Mafia association, an Italian court extinguished the sentence because it expired under Italian law, as more than double the penalty time had passed. Consequently, the European Arrest Warrant against the 65-year-old is being withdrawn, allowing him to stay in the UK, though his conviction remains intact. There has been criticism regarding the time and resources spent on the extradition proceedings, particularly concerning delays which may have contributed to the sentence expiring.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The other co-favourites are Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville. This race marks AP McCoy's final ride in a Grade One event. McCoy announced his retirement after riding Mr Mole to victory in February. Somersby is another runner in the chase. McCoy's full book of rides for his final day will be confirmed on Friday morning.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body for the first time, 40 years after the murder. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Ritter had initially followed her then-husband's advice not to see the photos but later regretted the decision and asked the lead police investigator to show them to her, expressing horror and anger upon viewing them. The case remained unsolved for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006 due to a DNA match from Marcia's clothing. In 2009, Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam, joining only five other players who have won all four major titles. He considers his final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011 the "most important day of his career," as he learned valuable lessons that helped him win his first major two months later. Despite only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, the world number one hopes to win multiple green jackets eventually. He plans to use the golf course as a "sanctuary" from the hype surrounding his attempt to complete the grand slam.

This week's trending stories included four rainbows appearing over the New York area after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis; a crackdown in rural China on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes; RDJ becoming agitated during an interview about his private life; the #kyliejennerchallenge lip plumping trend using jars to look like Kylie Jenner; 102-year-old Alice Barker going "back in time" with filmmakers; a controversial bomb-referencing prom-posal leading to accusations of racism; Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'; Johnny Depp's appearance in the 'Black Mass' trailer; a pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air"; and a military dad photobombing his son.

According to figures from the Health and Social Care Information Centre, 272 children were hospitalised in England last year due to brain damage from foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), caused by exposure to alcohol in the womb. Experts warn the actual number affected could be much higher, with World Health Organisation research suggesting 1 in 100 UK babies (around 7,500 annually) might suffer learning, behavioural, or physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure. FAS is described as a permanent and vastly under-diagnosed condition. Other associated medical issues include problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. Current government advice is for pregnant women not to drink, or to limit consumption to 1-2 units no more than twice a week, though some experts, like Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome, believe women should be advised not to drink at all during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender nicknamed "Boomerang Boy," attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores with an axe on March 15. While demanding cash from assistant Andrea Brighty, McKerry was tackled by the owner, Sab Dhillon. As they wrestled, Sab's wife, Sam, hit McKerry twice with

Four Royal Navy sailors (Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley) have been charged with the gang rape/sexual assault of a young woman at a party in a Canadian barracks in Nova Scotia. The alleged incident occurred on April 10 after the sailors, who were in Canada for an ice hockey tournament, returned from a game. They appeared in court in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, and were granted bail under conditions requiring them to surrender their passports, live at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax, remain employed by the Royal Navy, and stay in Nova Scotia until their trial. They are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, face up to

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an incredibly rare disease (affecting only about 70 people worldwide) that makes his skin appear red, inflamed, and scaly, resembling scalds or burns. Due to his appearance, a stranger reported Mrs. Jackson for child abuse, leading to her being surrounded by armed police while shopping. Mrs. Jackson and RJ face frequent public ignorance, including taunts, accusations of burning him, staring, and being denied entry to places like playhouses. She must constantly apply creams to manage his painful symptoms. Netherton's syndrome is a congenital condition with no cure, requiring intensive skin care, though symptoms may improve over time. Mrs. Jackson attributes the negative reactions to ignorance and hopes for greater awareness, emphasizing her love for her son despite the challenges.

Protein World's controversial "Are you beach body ready?" adverts, featuring model Renee Somerfield, are being removed from the London Underground by Transport for London (TfL). The campaign sparked significant backlash, including a petition with over 50,000 signatures, defaced posters, over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA), and a planned protest, due to concerns it promoted an unhealthy body image. TfL stated the removal coincided with the end of the paid advertising period but acknowledged the public reaction. Protein World defended the campaign aggressively, made controversial comments on social media, and reported receiving threats, including a bomb threat. The ASA is assessing the complaints.

Rail firms are facing criticism for planning significant fare increases, some up to 87 per cent, just ten days after the general election, despite pledges from major political parties to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has asked First Great Western (FGW) to urgently review an 87 per cent hike on the London to Cotswolds route, which affects his constituency, after constituents expressed anger. The planned increases primarily affect 'unregulated' fares like off-peak and advance tickets. FGW stated the change aligns the route with other services, while Virgin Trains, also implementing hikes, noted their overall increase is below average and affects specific, cheaper fare types. These increases contrast with promises by Mr. Cameron to freeze fares in real terms and Labour's pledge for a price cap.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after being attacked at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. Thugs were throwing stones at his property, and when Mr. Young opened his front door to confront them, he was struck in the left eye by a brick. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his sight. The attack occurred late one Friday night, just three weeks after Mr. Young married his wife, Elaine, 54. Police are investigating the incident, stating there appears to be no known motive, possibly just "yobs messing around," and are appealing for witnesses. Mr. Young feels unsafe in his home, and the couple plans to move away.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a new one-year contract extension, keeping him at the county until the end of the 2016 season. This follows his successful return from leg injuries sustained in a road accident in April 2014, which caused him to miss the entire 2014 season and resulted in the death of his father. After an ankle operation, the 25-year-old made his comeback during the pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and is available for the start of the season. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and hard work during his recovery.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with neuroblastoma cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, has been declared cancer-free by doctors. During his radiotherapy treatment, he decorated the protective mask used to keep him still like a Ninja Turtle, which helped him feel stronger and brave. Harley underwent intensive treatments including 80 days of chemotherapy, surgery to remove a kidney tumour, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy. His story gained media attention, resulting in gifts from Nickelodeon and him becoming the face of Cancer Research UK's kids and teens campaign. He is now doing well and will undergo regular check-ups. Neuroblastoma is a rare childhood cancer affecting specialised nerve cells, with fewer than 100 UK children diagnosed annually, mostly under five years old.

According to Tim Sherwood, Jack Grealish should concentrate on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future. Sherwood, impressed by the 19-year-old's performance against Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-final, believes Grealish needs to focus on securing his place in the Villa first team before deciding whether to represent the Republic of Ireland or England. Sherwood stated the choice is purely up to Grealish, comparing it to Nabil Bentaleb's decision between France and Algeria, and advised Grealish to "go with your heart". Grealish's father, Kevin, agreed with Sherwood's advice, emphasizing the need for his son to focus on club football first. Grealish, who has played for Ireland's youth teams, is expected to make his decision at the end of the season.

Landing fees for private jets vary dramatically across airports, contributing significantly to the high cost of this growing industry. Some surprisingly popular hubs for the wealthy, like Salzburg and Darwin, have high fees. The busiest and most expensive times for private jet travel often coincide with major sporting events such as the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix. A list compiled by The Richest, based on a 767-400 aircraft, identifies the most expensive airports for landing fees. Japan holds the top three spots with Haneda (Tokyo), Narita (Tokyo), and Kansai (Osaka). Other airports in the top 10 include Toronto Pearson, Darwin International, Bristol (the only UK airport listed), Chūbu Centrair (Nagoya), Dublin, La Guardia (New York - the only US airport listed), and Salzburg.

Katie Gallegos took her Labrador, Cooper, and his pal Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. A video captured Daisy taking small licks while Cooper devoured the cone in one bite. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, stated that Cooper always eats quickly, so she lets Daisy eat first. The video has garnered over seven million views, drawing both amusement and criticism. Gallegos defended giving the treat, asserting Cooper is healthy and receives ice cream occasionally, similar to her previous dog, Sammy. Daisy gets smaller portions due to her size. Another video shows Cooper similarly gulping down a Starbucks 'pup-uccino', which Gallegos clarified is just whipped cream.

Gary Locke has been appointed as Kilmarnock's permanent manager, signing a three-year deal. Locke, who joined as assistant boss last summer, took over as interim manager at the start of February when Allan Johnston quit. Since taking control, the 41-year-old has lost just one of seven games.

Jessica Kemp, a Florida mother from Eustis, accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because the Doterra essential oils she applies to his head and neck to keep him calm and focused were considered smelly and distracting by teachers. Kemp claims her son used the oils all year before a teacher's aide complained, and she received a letter from

A fire obliterated a 90-condo beach-side apartment complex, the Sandpiper complex, in Westhampton Beach on Wednesday afternoon. Smoke was visible from three miles away, and the blaze was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings before the structure collapsed. Twelve fire teams responded but could not get inside the building. The cause is unknown but is being investigated, with claims it may have started near a car. The complex is used as holiday homes between May and November, and the building manager who lived there lost everything.

The Queen, aged 88, was observed riding her Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She notably avoids wearing a riding helmet, opting for a silk scarf instead, reportedly because of her hair. Despite reducing her riding time due to a knee injury, she maintains a lifelong passion for horses, having started riding at age four. She continues to breed Thoroughbreds, Highland ponies, and Fell ponies. Fell ponies, like her mount, are an ancient, hardy breed with a history dating back to Neolithic times, used through Roman, Viking, and industrial periods before becoming popular riding ponies in the 1950s. The Queen breeds Fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud.

A noise dispute between Brisbane neighbours Leon Yeaman, 55, and Phillip Pama, 28, resulted in Yeaman's death. The incident occurred on Thursday night when Yeaman was allegedly making noise while Pama, an early shift worker, was trying to sleep. Pama confronted Yeaman, and during the altercation, Pama allegedly threw a single punch that killed Yeaman. Paramedics could not revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama has been charged with manslaughter and was granted conditional bail, requiring him to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and

Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho, 52, revealed that he talks to God every day but never about football, only praying for personal matters. The father-of-two also stated he does not discuss the game with his wife, trying to separate his professional and family life. He mentioned going to church regularly when in Portugal. Despite his professional persona, he claims to be a good person and friend. Mourinho and his family have worked with the World Food Programme as an ambassador against hunger.

On the April 1st edition of "The Price is Right," Bob Barker returned to the show for the first time in eight years. Barker, who hosted the game show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, hosted the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," at age 91. He then turned hosting duties over to Drew Carey. Despite his time away, Barker performed well.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested early Friday morning in Washington D.C. after allegedly attempting to break into a house on the 3200 block of D Street SE around midnight. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Following the arrest by the Metropolitan Police, the Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on administrative leave. Baldwin was assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch. His arrest follows other recent incidents of alleged misconduct within the agency, including a supervisor being placed on leave and an investigation into two officials driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, photographed a hungry male lion from just 10 feet away in the city's safari park. He left his car and crept towards the lion armed only with a camera. The clicking sound of the shutter alerted the lion, which jumped aggressively towards Saeed, forcing him to retreat rapidly back into his car. Saeed stated he wanted to capture the character and status of the lion but doesn't think he would repeat the close encounter.

New York City police are seeking help to identify a woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, who was found unconscious and pronounced dead on March 22 in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue. She had no identification, but police have released images of a distinctive tattoo on her right leg – a heart with a ribbon featuring the name 'Monique' and topped with a rose. The cause of death is pending a medical examiner's report. Police are asking anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck upon returning from the UK as they could not afford to buy property. The project took about a year and a half and cost approximately $25,000. The resulting two-bedroom home, constructed with wood and steel, allows them to live nearly self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand. It is primarily powered by solar panels, uses water from a nearby spring, and features a wood-fired stove.

Researchers claim that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests than those who do not use iPads or those who use them individually. A study by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University involving 352 kindergarten students found that shared iPad users scored approximately 30 points higher than the other groups. Blackwell suggests that the "collaborative learning around the technology" is the key factor, not just the technology or collaboration alone. She recommends that schools might reconsider how tablets are used, particularly in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness.

A piglet born without its back legs in Qionglai city, Sichuan province, China, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk and balance on its front trotters. A video shows the piglet, nicknamed 'super pig', taking unsteady steps and foraging for food while managing to regain its balance despite wobbling. Owned by farmer Ms. Duan, the piglet attracts villagers and happily mixes with its four-legged siblings. The passage notes this is not the first two-legged animal to gain attention in China, mentioning a rabbit that learned to walk on its front paws.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when struck by Francesco Dracone's car. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, received stitches for a cut on his leg, and was released. Many cars struggled with traction due to earlier rain. Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano (32) murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena (29), also known as Amanda Bueno, at their apartment in Rio de Janeiro. Horrific CCTV footage showed him smashing her head into concrete paving 11 times, punching her, and then shooting her in the face five times. Severiano confessed that he carried out the act because he was jealous of men looking at

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, known for the book "I Quit Sugar," revealed her personal battle with mental illness, specifically anxiety, which brought her close to taking her own life. In an interview with Women's Weekly Australia, the 41-year-old explained that a combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, distant family, and feeling isolated led her to believe her life wasn't worth living, stating she "couldn't see the point of continuing" or "a way out." Wilson, who felt very alone and like she had "missed out on a guide book to life" when younger, has recently found some peace and accepts being an "anxious person." She believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," stressing the need to acknowledge this link to better address the issue among Australian women.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant Oregon woman, was charged with second-degree assault after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom, and when the woman refused to leave, Curtin attacked her. Prosecutors dropped the charges before trial, stating Curtin was 'completely justified in

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed being fed treats by her owner. As a trick, the owner included a broccoli spear, which Gemma reacted to with disgust, chomped on, and then spat out onto the floor. The passage notes this isn't a good example for the two children she lives with, hoping they learn to love their greens. When not eating, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was for the bank's young entrepreneur awards page, which had been shut down. The porn site took over the address after the awards were scrapped in 2011 and the registration for the URL expired. HSBC removed the hyperlink, denied any association with the external site, issued a public apology for the inconvenience, and insisted its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 on Sunday morning after a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, in a second-floor bedroom. During the 11-minute call, Marcus remained calm, provided instructions to firefighters, and soothed his sister. Firefighters entered the room through the home, broke a window, and rescued the siblings. Firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus out the window and gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. The siblings were taken to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while three other family members who escaped on their own were also hospitalized.

Amazing pictures have emerged of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay on the NSW south coast. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the neon glow, describing it as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of light-omitting plankton. According to Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales, the phenomenon is caused by *Noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn and glows as a defense mechanism. A similar display occurred in Manly Beach in 2014, with experts stating there was no cause for concern.

New genetic tests can analyze breast cancer tumours after surgery to pinpoint genetic markers and determine the risk of the cancer returning. These tests allow doctors to identify patients with a low risk of recurrence (as low as 5%), potentially sparing them from undergoing chemotherapy and its difficult side effects, such as hair loss, nausea, and fatigue. Currently, most women receive chemotherapy after tumour removal as a standard precaution. One specific test mentioned is EndoPredict. While these tests are mostly available privately at a cost of around £2,500, specialists hope they will become available on the NHS, arguing the cost could be balanced by savings from reduced chemotherapy use. Experts believe these tests enable patients to make more informed decisions about their treatment.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious. A Ministry of Defence spokesman indicated a 'no touching' rule at sea suggests conception occurred before boarding or during leave. Separately, 99 servicewomen were flown back from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material (cesium), a small camera, and smoke flares was discovered on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence. While the amount of cesium was not immediately harmful, the incident has raised concerns about potential drone terrorism, especially with the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit. The government plans to review drone operation regulations and anti-terrorism measures. The discovery occurred on the same day a court approved restarting nuclear reactors, and current law does not restrict drone flights over most of Tokyo, including the Prime Minister's residence. The Prime Minister was not present at the time.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in China's Zhejiang province, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. He secures her with a sash tied around both their waists to prevent her from falling off during the four-kilometre journey, which he rides slowly. Lu began doing this after his father passed away, fearing his mother would get lost if left alone, as she had previously wandered off. His wife works in another city and his son is in school. His employer, a bank, has provided a room for his mother, and Lu checks on her frequently during his workday. He feels it is his duty to care for her in return for the care she gave him.

UN officials, specifically the World Health Organisation (WHO), warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. They state the procedure should only be carried out when "medically necessary" due to potential complications like infections, disability, or death. In England, over a quarter of births are now caesareans, more than double the rate since the early 1990s, whereas the WHO recommends an ideal rate between 10% and 15%. The WHO highlights the risks and higher costs (£2,369 vs £1,665 for a natural birth in the NHS), noting this contradicts current NHS guidelines which allow the procedure for maternal anxiety (tokophobia) even without medical justification. Planned caesareans are also advised in England for previous complicated births, women over

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owner's belongings in a yard sale. She was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, on April 17 in the Edgartown property. Filkins initially claimed ownership, fled when police were called, but was arrested later when she attempted to return. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket. She faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. A witness reported seeing her with items from the home, appearing to have a yard sale. Missing items include furniture, a grill, lamps, and a painting. Police are asking for the return of these items and for anyone with

Bella Crooke's lost iPhone was handed into Albury police station. Finding the phone unlocked, officers posted selfies and humorous updates on her Facebook page to track her down, including photos of the phone in a holding "cell" and puns about it being "charged". Bella, who had lost the phone at a party, arrived at the station unaware of the posts but was recognized by the officers. She found their actions humorous, thanked them, and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa after getting caught in a fight between two adult male hippos. One of the adults grabbed the calf, threw it into the air, and dragged it through the water while the calf's mother watched from the herd. The baby hippo died from its injuries hours later. The event was witnessed by tour operator Stacey Farrell.

A computer outage late Friday affected registers at 8,000 Starbucks stores across the US and Canada, preventing staff from ringing up sales or accepting credit cards. The outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh and also impacted Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. As a result, many baristas gave away free drinks and baked goods, leading to excitement on social media, though some stores closed early to avoid giving away products. Starbucks announced the issue was resolved by Saturday morning, with stores expected to open as usual. This incident occurred the day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings.

According to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, terrorists are undergoing training and radicalizing Muslims in rural areas of West Wales, specifically mentioning locations in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. He stated that those involved participate in "seemingly ordinary activities" but possess an "ulterior motive." Jones emphasized that terrorism issues are not confined to large cities and cited historical incidents of extremist activity in Wales dating back to 1998, including links to Abu Hamza, two 7/7 bombers, Cardiff plotters arrested in 2010, and Michael Adebowale, who studied near Llanybydder. He also stressed the importance of community intelligence.

An Omura's whale, a species previously feared extinct and about which little is known, washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in West Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and the second in Australia. The 5.68m juvenile female was identified via DNA profiling. The discovery is considered highly significant for scientists, providing an opportunity to learn more about the mammal, which was first described in 2003 and is usually found in tropical/subtropical waters like Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The species has unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and possible museum display.

The passage discusses the argument made by businesswoman Cheryl Rios that Hillary Clinton's hormones make her unfit for the presidency, suggesting women shouldn't lead. The author counters this by questioning the role of male hormones in past leaders' decisions, citing studies showing women leaders take fewer risks, and noting scandals involving male politicians. The author argues that the focus on hormones distracts from the pervasive gender bias women face in leadership and the workplace, providing examples like corporate board composition and differing evaluations of male and female professors. The passage concludes that this bias hinders female candidates and that achieving gender equality benefits companies, families, and society overall, also noting that Canada has already had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell.
Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling his extensive collection of antiques in a £100,000 auction because he is downsizing his home. The auction

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted by police as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, and has been on the run since Saturday. He came to the attention of authorities after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the day his mother was found dead in the Winter Garden home they shared, following a well-being check requested by an out-of-state family member. Police determined foul play was involved. Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was previously involuntarily committed. He was going through a divorce, which neighbors believe may have contributed to the situation, possibly triggered by receiving "bad news" paperwork or his mother allegedly preventing him from attending the visit with his son. He was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. Police have recovered the murder weapon but have not confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Authorities are asking anyone with information on his whereabouts to contact them.

Eugene, USA, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The IAAF council decided to bypass the usual bidding process, citing a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the event in the USA for the first time and access a key market. Eugene had previously failed in its bid for the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka were also awarded without a bidding process.

Aspiring model Leonie Granger targeted professional gambler Mehmet Hassan after seeing him with cash at a casino. She befriended him, went back to his flat, and left the door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler. The two men tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home, stealing cash. Following a trial, Granger was convicted of manslaughter and jailed for 16 years. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and jailed for life with a minimum term of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked".

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas is experiencing a dip in form during the second half of the season, continuing a trend noted during his time at Barcelona. Despite a strong start where he seemed poised to break the Premier League assist record, his performance has declined significantly since Christmas, evidenced by a poor showing for Spain against Holland and a drop in his assist rate. While Chelsea is likely to win the league title, manager Jose Mourinho is concerned about Fabregas's fatigue and durability, hoping for a resurgence to help secure the championship.

West Ham are discussing a deal for 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed coaches during a two-week trial. Beckford, considered a top Caribbean prospect, also has offers from Belgian clubs, but West Ham are reportedly closing in on signing him. Additionally, West Ham announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the cheapest in the Premier League, as part of a strategy to fill the 54,000-capacity venue for the 2016-17 season.

Wiltshire Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, three months after the incident, citing insufficient evidence. Lane was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters with iron bars during a hunt using an artificial scent, suffering concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Despite police receiving video footage (including the face of the main suspect), names of saboteurs, and car registration numbers, the investigation has been halted, a decision Lane called "pathetic." Hunt supporters expressed dismay, noting the difficulty in identifying attackers wearing face coverings. The police stated the case is recorded as "undetected" but could be reopened if further evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, known as the "American mouthpiece of al Qaeda," was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, although he was not specifically targeted. Born in California in 1978, he converted to Islam, moved to Pakistan in 1998, and joined al Qaeda, eventually becoming its chief English-language propagandist. He appeared in numerous videos threatening attacks, criticizing U.S. presidents, urging lone-wolf attacks, and praising other attackers. Gadahn was indicted for treason in 2006 and was on the FBI's

A viral video in China showcases a five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo displaying a dazzling array of basketball skills, including scoring successive hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. Mai Zizhuo has been playing since he was two and a half years old. His incredible skills have won him legions of fans across basketball-mad China, stunning netizens who have left thousands of comments expressing disbelief and praise. The passage also mentions Yao Ming as the country's biggest basketball star previously.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to be used as a unique catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation as part of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. This displaced the daily lap swimmers. Ten Pieces, headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, presented a unisex, monochrome collection of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 ways. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop. Crowds gathered on the club's balcony and passers-by watched from the road above, while guests enjoyed nibbles and drinks in the warm, sunny weather.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan visited Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, a safari park in Northern California, with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. During the family trip, Khan posed with and fed a white tiger, and they also posed with giraffes and sea lions. This outing followed Khan's recent announcement that his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about potential fights against Kell Brook, Adrien Broner, or Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name was removed from an Israeli memorial for fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism at Mount Herzl after complaints from his family and others. The 16-year-old Palestinian, killed by three Israelis, was initially included on the memorial wall and website. His father objected, refusing to have his son listed with Israeli soldiers and stating permission wasn't sought. An Israeli victims' organization, Almagor, also opposed the inclusion, arguing his death was a "rogue attack" and not terrorism. Consequently, the National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial, removed Abu Khdeir's name from the wall and its website.

YouTube user Lionel Hutz filmed his young son attempting to use the family cat's belly as a pillow while in the garden. The footage shows the boy repeatedly lying on the cat, which gets up and moves away each time. This occurs multiple times before the cat goes indoors. A subsequent video shows the boy and cat having made up, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past years selling marijuana. Kushner, one of over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the government, told jurors that officers on trial had stolen $81,000 and marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. This history was news to the school, where he had passed a background check in 2010. Kushner acknowledged past arrests in 2007 (expunged) and 2011 (probation), and a 2008 DUI plea. He stated he never meant to deceive the school and considered his past dealing phase over.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, injured six people and sparked a large fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a controversial chemical. The blast occurred Monday night at an oil storage facility following an oil leak, though no toxic chemical spill has been reported by local media. Five of the injured were hurt by broken glass. Over 600 firefighters were dispatched, and the fire is now under control. Residents heard the explosion and felt tremors. The same plant experienced an explosion in July 2013. The construction of PX plants has led to protests in China due to pollution concerns, and this specific plant was relocated from Xiamen in 2007 following public backlash.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, is renowned for wearing his socks low, just above his shinpads, due to superstition. He states he will continue this habit, which he has done all his life, despite referees telling him to pull them up. Grealish uses children's size shinpads and mentioned he hasn't received a kick on his shin yet. He recently made his first Premier League start for Villa against QPR, a tough game he was pleased to start, and hopes for more starts before the season ends, boosted by the manager's faith in him.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Although no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and could live in this condition for a lifetime. This contrasts with statements from her father, Bobby Brown, who said she was "awake" and "watching" him, and a family attorney who indicated her condition has improved, doctors suggest a long life, but she is starting a long rehabilitation process with an unknown future quality of life. A source confirmed she remains in the same unresponsive neurological state and has a tracheostomy.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie. Svetlana Kuznetsova won the opening rubber against Julia Goerges in straight sets. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova then beat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, after saving a match point in the second set. Pavlyuchenkova noted Lisicki's powerful "boom-boom" style caused her problems, while Lisicki acknowledged she didn't play a good tiebreaker after having a match point. Lisicki's 63 unforced errors were crucial, despite Pavlyuchenkova's 13 double faults. Russia needs one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and aim for their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage, as another storm, potentially an east coast low similar to last week's, is predicted to hit later this week, possibly starting Thursday. Meteorologists expect heavy rain, particularly impacting coastal areas in the state's north-east. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that this new weather event will hamper ongoing clean-up efforts from the previous storm, which left over 4,000 jobs outstanding. The SES is particularly worried about the already hard-hit Hunter region and urges the community to prepare their homes and families. While the new system might differ slightly from the last, further rainfall on saturated ground is expected to raise flood levels again.

Model Nina Moric, known for appearing in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, was hospitalized over the weekend. Italian media reported that she attempted suicide and was found by her mother, with her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso quoted confirming the attempt. However, Moric denied these claims on her Instagram account, stating she collapsed due to low blood pressure, hitting her head and causing bruises which she showed in photographs. She clarified her boyfriend was in Naples at the time of the incident and reassured fans she was recovering at home. Italian media had previously claimed Moric attempted suicide in 2009. Moric was formerly married to paparazzi Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son.

As Kate and William prepare for their second child, a YouGov poll for the Sunday Times indicates the British public hopes for a traditional name. Diana is the favourite choice if the baby is a girl, receiving 12% of the vote, followed by Alice and Charlotte at 9% each. If the baby is a boy, James is the preferred name (13%), followed by Alexander. The poll also revealed that 25% of respondents hope for a girl, compared to 3% hoping for a boy. Social media users echoed the preference for the name Diana. Furthermore, 68% of people polled support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, according to police chief Faizullah Ghairat. An Afghan lawmaker, Humayoon Humayoon, who was participating in the protest against the provincial governor, was among the wounded. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack.

Dani Alves looks set to leave Barcelona this summer as his representative, Dinorah Santana, confirmed he rejected the club's final contract offer. Alves, a 31-year-old right-back who has been with Barcelona for seven successful years, winning multiple titles, was offered a three-year extension contingent on playing in 60% of matches. Santana stated that negotiations are now over, expressing frustration that the club waited until April to address the contract renewal.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton where he has scored three goals in six games, has urged Italian players Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo believes the duo, whom he considers friends and has played with, would be a perfect fit for Boca due to their "South-American style" and abilities. He stated that the fans at La Bombonera would go "absolutely crazy" for players like them.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson was back mucking out stables as usual at Paul Nicholls's yard on Thursday morning, showing only a cut on his nose from a spectacular double somersault fall the previous day. The fall occurred while riding Merrion Square at Wincanton and has become an internet sensation, viewed hundreds of thousands of times online. Ferguson described the fall as a "blur," felt lucky to have avoided serious injury, and is undeterred, having already returned to riding out. He gained Twitter followers and received some banter following the incident.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker, posted an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man, coinciding with the release of the *Avengers: Age of Ultron* movie. Haskell first joined Wasps in 2002, left in 2009 to play for Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and the Highlanders, before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since his return, he has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and has earned 57 England caps.

The wide leg trouser is a key trend for SS15, presented as an effortless alternative to skinny jeans which have been popular for years. This look, which has made comebacks since the seventies, can be intimidating, particularly for shorter individuals. However, styling advice includes wearing high heels (especially with cropped styles) to elongate the leg and keeping the top half simple (like a knit, shirt, or tee) to maintain proportion. For longer lengths, a high-waisted, very long style is recommended. Denim is cited as the easiest way to adopt the trend, with examples from Gucci and Topshop. Other designers like Celine and Stella McCartney showcased dressier versions. The trend is suitable for updating a spring wardrobe and doesn't depend on nice weather.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" after initially cancelling it due to a student petition. Over 200 students signed the petition, arguing the movie reflected negatively on the Middle East and its people. However, following a backlash and a counter-petition, the university reversed its decision, citing its commitment to freedom of expression and student choice. The screening will take place as part of the UMix social events, with the film "Paddington" offered as an alternative.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly attempted to set a quokka alight on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3 by igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter. The quokka survived the incident but was singed. Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, and evicted them from the island. Both men have been charged with animal cruelty and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are described as being the size of a domestic cat and are found on small islands off the West Australian coast, including Rottnest Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old woman, was a chorus line dancer in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club during the 1930s and 1940s, performing alongside notables such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Although motion pictures were made of her, she had never seen them, and her photos and memorabilia were lost. Filmmakers Mark Cantor and volunteers found early music videos ("soundies") featuring Barker and showed them to her at her nursing home. Seeing herself dance for the first time, Barker was delighted, calling the experience "fabulous".

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's significant impact on him since Skrtel joined Liverpool in 2008, stating Gerrard helped him settle at the club. Skrtel considers Gerrard, who is leaving for LA Galaxy after the season, to still be one of the world's best players and synonymous with Liverpool. While acknowledging Liverpool will be different without him, Skrtel believes the club has players who can replace Gerrard and that the team will work together to help them. Gerrard hopes to end his Liverpool career by winning the FA Cup final, potentially on his birthday. Both Skrtel and Gerrard could return from suspension for the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National, playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This was Nicklaus's first ace at Augusta. Despite his achievement, Camilo Villegas also hit two aces on the same day (on the fourth and eighth holes), contributing to a record-tying total of five holes-in-one for the event. Kevin Streelman ultimately won the Par-3 contest in a play-off against Villegas. The passage also mentions Nicklaus's past accomplishments, including being the youngest Masters winner in 1963, winning his sixth Green Jacket in 1986, and being one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens were activated in Kansas due to storms bringing reports of twisters, including one spotted near Goddard, west of Wichita, and others in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. A CNN severe weather expert noted that nighttime tornadoes are the most dangerous. The storms also impacted Missouri, with the National Weather Service indicating a possible tornado touchdown in Potosi, where wind damage, flooding, and large hail were reported. More storms were forecast for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris on April 2. Bates claims he intended to use a Taser but mistakenly fired his gun. A judge granted Bates permission to vacation in the Bahamas, which drew criticism from Harris' family, who called it a message of apathy. Bates' preliminary hearing is set for July 2. Allegations have surfaced that Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and his friendship with the sheriff, claims denied by the sheriff's office but supported by reports of supervisors being asked to forge records. Bates' lawyer released training documents asserting he was properly trained. Bates and Sheriff Stanley Glanz have apologized to the Harris family. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the encounter, McGregor revealed a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach, adding to his existing gorilla tattoo on his chest. McGregor claims he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time. The pair have a fractious relationship, demonstrated when McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a schooner of beer in about six seconds at an Australian rules function, cheered on by players. This action drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners, notably cultural studies professor Julie Robert, who stated it was 'problematic' as it glorified binge drinking, associated masculinity with alcohol, and promoted a culture of drinking quickly rather than socializing. While opposition leader Bill Shorten quipped about the incident, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, highlighting his fitness. Dr. Robert noted that while other prime ministers like Bob Hawke have skolled beers, attitudes towards binge drinking have since changed, and critics believe Abbott should set a different example.

An obsessive Arsenal fan created a detailed test about the football club for his girlfriend, Saskia, formatting it like a school exam with multiple-choice questions, tables, and written sections. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%), prompting her boyfriend to comment that he would not dump her as a result. She posted pictures of the test, marked in red pen with feedback including notes like 'learn all player positions' and 'Tottenham are scum', to her Twitter account. Despite struggling with naming the full starting 11 and some player positions, she gained points for creative answers, such as describing Alexis Sanchez as 'buff' and Eden Hazard as a 'p***k'. The boyfriend graded her test 'A', and the incident received mixed reactions online, with some calling the boyfriend a 'legend' and Saskia 'proper gf material', while others felt he had gone too far.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel who fled Colombia fearing for his life, worked as an informant for the DEA for 27 years. He provided information that aided in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Toro was promised US citizenship in exchange for his work but never received it. Now 66 and retired due to declining health, his temporary visa has expired, and he faces deportation to Colombia, where he fears he will be killed. The DEA refused to help with his citizenship after he went public with his situation. His former DEA handler, Mike McManus, supports Toro, stating he deserves to live in the US after his service. Toro is currently in legal limbo, unable to collect social security, and seeking a green card or passport.
A 14-year-old girl in Uttar Pradesh, India, set herself on fire, suffering 70

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is preparing for the upcoming derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford, expressing his dream of winning the match. Key players Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw have been ruled out by Van Gaal due to not meeting his fitness standards, despite Van Persie stating he was fit. Van Gaal views a victory as a crucial step towards potentially finishing second or third in the league and securing Champions League qualification. He downplayed revenge for a previous loss to City, stressing the need for controlled aggression, and expressed anticipation for the Old Trafford derby atmosphere and appreciation for the fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices at their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. They left seats empty for the first 10 minutes and displayed banners inside and outside the ground, reacting to rising costs, such as the £64 starting ticket price for the match, especially following the announcement of the £5.14bn TV rights deal. One banner read, "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket". Fan groups, including Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, organized the event, calling prices "extortionate" and demanding reductions.

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with the life-threatening liver condition biliary atresia shortly after birth, indicated by jaundice. An initial operation to unblock her bile ducts was unsuccessful, necessitating a liver transplant for survival. Neither of her parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were suitable donors. Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader (her mother's twin sister), volunteered and was found to be a suitable match, donating part of her liver. The transplant operation took place in November, and after six weeks in the hospital, Star returned home and has made a good recovery, though she will require lifelong medication and regular tests.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake teamed up against Loic Remy and Willian for an Audi football challenge. The challenges involved firing balls into a car boot from close range, playing football "tennis" over an Audi R8 V10 plus, and shooting footballs into a convertible Audi from long range. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, leading 6-0. Remy and Willian won the final long-range challenge, but during this round, Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror off one of the Audis.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed Amanda Murphy, Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby, Reagan Elizabeth. Dellinger drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph, hitting their SUV. Prosecutors initially said Dellinger told investigators he was trying to kill himself, but during his sentencing, Dellinger stated he was not suicidal and had never been. His defense attorneys claimed factors like Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose effects, Prozac, and multiple sclerosis symptoms contributed to the crash. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent

Lacey Spears was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, whom prosecutors said she poisoned with salt through his feeding tube. Spears, who appeared emotionless during sentencing, was spared the maximum 25 years to life. The boy's father, Chris Hill, reacted angrily on Facebook, expressing hope she would suffer or die in prison. Prosecutors argued Spears made her son ill for attention, using his illnesses to "self aggrandize herself," while her lawyer claimed she was innocent, blamed hospital negligence, and plans to appeal. The judge stated Spears suffers from a mental illness but called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty."

An improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia, delayed by a month, because scientists have added protection against two new strains: influenza A (H3N2) and influenza B (B/Phuket). This decision was made after these strains caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the US due to the previous vaccine not being a good match. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, can access free government-funded shots from April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, state the

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing challenges coinciding with the 150th anniversary of his assassination. These include an unflattering critique in *National Geographic* magazine, which described the tomb as disappointing and lacking historical character ("office lobby," "incongruous art deco style"), and potential budget cuts proposed by Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner that could eliminate the state historic preservation agency managing the site. Previous funding cuts have already reduced hours and staffing. Supporters defend the tomb, citing over $2.5 million in recent renovations that leave it in "excellent physical condition" and arguing the critique is unfair. The tomb, designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated in 1874, has been reconstructed twice, most recently in 1930.

The passage discusses the current resurgence of nineties fashion trends such as chokers and Calvin Klein logos. However, it highlights the potential comeback of JNCO wide-leg jeans as horrifying to many who wore them previously. This prompts a list of nine nineties and noughties fashion trends deemed "worst offenders" that perhaps should stay in the past. These trends include: bucket hats, camouflage print, taking trends to the maximum (like double denim), Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes (tiny denim shorts), Juicy Couture tracksuits, coloured sunglasses, corsets worn as outerwear, and harem trousers. For each trend, the passage notes celebrities associated with it in the past and present.

This week's trending stories included four rainbows appearing over the New York area after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis; China's crackdown on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for funerals; Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during an interview about his private life; the #kyliejennerchallenge lip plumping trend inspired by Kylie Jenner; 102-year-old Alice Barker going "back in time" with filmmakers; a controversial prom-posal referencing bombs leading to accusations of racism; Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'; Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the
Following Andy Murray's 500th win celebration, Serena Williams received a large cake at the Miami Open after achieving her 700th career

Sabeen Mahmud ran "The Second Floor" cafe in Karachi, Pakistan, a vibrant space for discussions on technology, human rights, and politics. Known for her brave exercise of free speech in a country where it is dangerous, she was shot dead by gunmen after closing her cafe. The attack occurred shortly after she hosted a controversial discussion on disappearances in Balochistan, a topic authorities had previously shut down elsewhere and for which she had received prior threats. Her mother was also shot but survived. Mahmud was seen as a figurehead for humanism and tolerance, and her death prompted widespread grief. No group has claimed responsibility for the shooting.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, is one of around 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) living in Indian Kashmir since fleeing the 1947 partition. For nearly 70 years, these refugees, mostly residing in the Jammu region, have been denied state citizenship rights, preventing them from owning property, voting in state elections, or holding state government jobs. This status has trapped generations in poverty. The denial stems from the ongoing Kashmir dispute and fears by successive state governments of upsetting the demographic balance in the Muslim-majority state. With Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist BJP party gaining a share of power in Kashmir, there is renewed hope among the WPRs that they will finally be granted full rights, though activists warn of potential unrest if their situation does not improve.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential summer move to Chelsea after the Premier League club reportedly made an offer of around £4 million, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. Muto stated he wants to carefully consider the offer, seeking a club where he can play regularly and develop, amidst suggestions Chelsea might loan him to Vitesse Arnhem. Muto's former coach, Ranko Popovic, praised his intelligence, speed, strength, and potential. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged awareness of Muto but declined detailed comment, while also noting that commercial interests, alongside player quality and Financial Fair Play, are considerations in the club's transfer policy.

Open Garden's FireChat app allows users to chat without internet or mobile signals by creating wireless mesh networks between phones, utilizing features like Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework. Phones act as nodes, passing messages directly within a limited range (around 200ft). To enhance these networks, Open Garden is developing Greenstone, a small, egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster. Greenstone is designed to strengthen the mesh network, help messages travel further, and provide resilient communication, especially in situations without connectivity or where

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is working to remove the negative connotations of the word "fat" by using it as a neutral descriptor for her own body, similar to how she uses "short" or "wife." In a TED Talk, she argued that "fat" should not be synonymous with "ugly," despite societal pressures and statistics showing size discrimination and young girls' desire to be thinner. Bustle believes exposure to body diversity increases acceptance, which motivates her burlesque performances as a way to present a "fat" body positively. She shared her personal journey, starting burlesque in 2012, which empowered her and provided a "courage reference" for moments of insecurity. Her TED Talk video has received largely positive feedback, reinforcing her belief in the progress of body positivity.

Theo Walcott, who has frequently been on the substitutes' bench for Arsenal this season (17 out of 33 league games), participated in a photoshoot for the fashion house Lanvin, the club's official tailor since 2013. He posed alongside teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and runway model Olga Sherer.
