The Arsenal team will wear similar attire for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa. Walcott hopes to make his first start since March 14 in the upcoming match against Hull.

Seven-year-old British boy Carwyn Scott-Howell died during a family ski holiday in the French Alps after becoming separated from his mother and falling 164ft off a drop in dense woodland. Described by his family as a "daring, outgoing and determined" and competent skier, his death has left a "vast void in their hearts." Police followed footprints and sliding marks in the snow to find his body; it's believed he left the piste trying to head towards the resort he saw through the trees. His family, friends, and school community

Laura Scurr, a teenager from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 due to bullying about her weight and societal pressure to be "size zero." Her obsession led her to drastically restrict her food intake, sometimes surviving on just one piece of fruit or 100 calories a day, and hiding food from her mother. This severe starvation caused her body to shut down, leading to a collapse and hospitalization where she was placed on a heart monitor for a week. After receiving support from eating disorder organizations (EDICT and CAMHS), Laura recovered. She now has improved body image and confidence, reaching the semi-finals of the Miss Teen GB competition, which aims to challenge size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool players, including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, unveiled the club's new gingham-designed home kit at Anfield. The kit is the first from New Balance under a record £300 million four-year deal, replacing Warrior. During the launch, fans urged Sterling to stay at the club, following his recent rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract and comments linking him to Arsenal. Liverpool maintains that Sterling, who has two years left on his contract, will not leave this summer. Players also spoke about the fans and the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa. The new shirt features white branding, a new collar style, and a tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven winger Memphis Depay. PSV's technical director confirmed the contact, noting that Paris Saint-Germain and another major European club are also interested. United manager Louis van Gaal, who coached Depay in the Dutch national team during the 2014 World Cup where Depay scored twice, is keen to sign the 21-year-old. Depay has had a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in
Chelsea defeated Manchester City's youth side 3-1 in Manchester. Tammy Abraham scored a double for Chelsea in the first half, and Dominic Solanke

Marco Rubio stated on CBS's Face the Nation that he believes people are "born with a sexual preference," but insists the "definition of the institution of marriage should be between one man and one woman." He argues that same-sex marriage is not a constitutional right and that states, not courts, should regulate marriage through political debate in state legislatures. Rubio, a presidential candidate, also previously said he would attend the same-sex wedding of someone he cared for out of love and respect, even if he disagreed with the decision.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple cycling around the world with the dream of discovering the planet "a pedal at a time." Having quit their jobs, they embarked on an open-ended journey starting in London. In their first 356 days, they covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, heading south-east through Europe and into Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia. They live extremely frugally on less than three euros each per day, keeping costs down by cycling for transport and primarily using free accommodation like camping, hosting websites (Couchsurfing, Warmshowers), or relying on strangers' kindness. Food (pasta, bread, rice, fruit/veg, supplemented by gifts, wild fruit, and dumpster diving) is their main expense at 2.74 euros daily. They plan to continue through Asia, cross the Pacific, cycle the Americas, and anticipate being on the road for several more years.

A Texas couple, married in 2012, is suing James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, alleging that racial slurs were printed on the bottom of photo booth snapshots taken at their wedding. The couple was informed about the incident months after the event by the bride's sister. When the groom contacted Evans, Evans allegedly did not apologize and told him to "sue me". Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, the couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the allegations, claiming no evidence links his company to the offensive caption. According to Hale, the couple primarily seeks an apology. Mediation is scheduled

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a 'cautious' approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback and is unsure when he will return to play for Harlequins. He pulled out of the Saracens match after experiencing a headache following the France game, deciding not to risk a long-term absence like Johnny Sexton or Geoff Parling. Brown, who was previously knocked out cold against Italy in February, credits increased awareness from World Rugby online modules for helping him recognise symptoms and pull out of the Ireland game. He is taking his recovery stage by stage and stresses the importance of players being honest about symptoms and not playing through them.

According to Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency with which couples have sex. Research indicates that sexual frequency among Britons has decreased since the emergence of the internet, with typical heterosexual couples now having sex three times a month, down from five times a month in 1990. Spiegelhalter suggests that increased technological connectivity blurs the lines between public and private lives, fills quiet time with activities like checking emails, and erodes boundaries between home and work, thus squeezing out time for partners. Researcher Catherine Mercer supports this, stating that competing demands push sex down the priority list and that late-night connectivity (like dealing with work emails) prevents focus on a partner at bedtime.

Tibetan Mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80kg and once commanded prices as high as £1.2 million, have dramatically declined in popularity in China. This decline is partly blamed on the government's anti-corruption crackdown, which stopped the practice of gifting these dogs to officials, and bans on owning large dogs (over 50kg) in several cities. Poor breeding practices leading to a glut of low-quality dogs and the breed's unsuitability for urban living also contributed. Consequently, Tibetan Mastiffs are now being sent to slaughterhouses for meat used in hotpots and skin for leather belts, with animal welfare workers rescuing some found in cruel conditions en route.

A survey of 600 women around Paris found that every woman surveyed claimed to have been a victim of sexual harassment on the city's public transport, with half experiencing it first before the age of 18. The harassment ranges from insults and intimidating behaviour to sexual assault and rape. This issue causes fear in six out of ten women (compared to three out of ten men) and limits their freedom by forcing them to alter their daily lives (routes, schedules, clothing). The report, handed to the French women's rights ministry, stated this serves to "exclude women from the public arena". The poll led to calls for a campaign against such behaviour, with experts emphasizing the need to educate women that this is not normal, that attackers often feel impunity, and that acts like unwanted touching constitute sexual assault with

Leeds-based company Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix to design prototype products addressing common "everyday emergencies". These emergencies were identified through a survey of 2,000 people, with the top issue being inability to sleep. Groups from London-based design company Makerversity created products, and three were shortlisted:
1.  **Snooze:** An alarm clock by Instruments that connects to a phone and silences notifications to aid sleep.
2.  **Forget Me Lock:** A device by Onn Studio that attaches to a key, showing red when locked and green when open, to confirm if the door is locked.
3.  **Nipper:** Claimed by creators Impulse to be the world's smallest mobile charger, using household batteries for power.

The public can vote for their favourite prototype on Twitter by retweeting using the #everydayfix hashtag. The product with the most retweets by 46 April will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product. Other prototypes that didn't make the shortlist included a cycling helmet with bone conduction headphones, a parking pin alert system, and an app to relay messages when a phone battery dies.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC) for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice after allocating over £500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity where she serves as a director. Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim, also sits on the charity's board. This decision, made after PCCs were allowed to commission victim services, has drawn criticism, with figures like Keith Vaz calling it "inappropriate" and a conflict of interest, likening the situation to a "soap opera". Baird defends her actions, stating Ministry of Justice procedures were followed. The Ministry of Justice is investigating the potential conflict of interest. Sue Sim, who previously faced a bullying investigation led by Baird, has announced her retirement.

Three individuals have been imprisoned for assaulting 53-year-old Greg Valecce in a Philadelphia basement. Corry 'Corey' Campbell, the ringleader of the group known as the 'tattoo terrorists', believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and stolen money and weed. Over three days, Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos by Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, and Carl Halin. Valecce suffered multiple injuries but escaped. Campbell and Halin were sentenced to 20 years in prison, and Ng received 23 months. Two other individuals, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing or trial for their roles.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated he believes people are "born with a sexual preference." While he personally believes the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman, he insists that state legislatures, not courts, should decide whether to allow gay marriage, asserting it is not a constitutional right. Rubio also said he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of love and respect, even if he disagreed with the decision, comparing this stance to his Catholic view on divorce.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are on an open-ended cycling journey to discover the world "a pedal at a time," having quit their jobs in Manchester. In nearly a year (356 days), they have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, starting in London and travelling through Europe into Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia. They live extremely frugally on less than three euros each per day, primarily by camping or using hosting websites (Couchsurfing, Warmshowers) for accommodation and eating basic foods like pasta, bread, and rice, sometimes supplemented by free food or dumpster diving. They plan to continue through Asia, cross the Pacific, cycle the Americas, and remain on the road for years.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a 'cautious' approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback and is unsure when he will return to play for his club, Harlequins. He pulled out of a recent match against Saracens after experiencing a headache following the England vs. France game. Brown, who was knocked out cold against Italy in February, wants to avoid a long break like Johnny Sexton or George North and credits increased awareness from World Rugby online modules for helping him recognise symptoms and prioritise his health over playing, even pulling out of the crucial Ireland game earlier in the season. He stresses the importance of being honest about symptoms and not risking playing while concussed.

According to Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in the frequency with which couples have sex. Research indicates that sexual frequency among Britons has decreased since the emergence of the internet, with typical heterosexual couples now having sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter suggests that increased technological connectivity has blurred the lines between public and private lives, home and work, reducing quiet time as people constantly check emails. This busyness squeezes out time for partners. Researcher Catherine Mercer adds that competing demands lower sex on priority lists, and dealing with work emails late at night hinders the ability to focus on a partner at bedtime.

Tibetan Mastiffs, large dogs weighing up to 80kg traditionally used for herding in Tibet, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity in China. Once status symbols commanding prices as high as £1.2 million, they are now being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat (used in hotpots) and skin (used for leather). This decline is attributed to several factors: the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown preventing their use as gifts to officials, bans on owning large dogs (over 50kg) in several major cities, a glut of poor-quality dogs resulting from cross-breeding for profit, and a growing realization that they are unsuitable for city living due to urbanization. Animal welfare workers have rescued mastiffs found in cruel conditions en route to slaughter, and gangs are reportedly stealing them for the same purpose.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, ran a competition called #everydayfix where groups from the design company Makerversity designed prototype products to solve common "everyday emergencies." These emergencies were identified through a survey of 2,000 people, with top issues including not being able to sleep, forgetting to lock the door, and phone batteries running out. Three prototypes were shortlisted: 'Snooze,' an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; 'Forget Me Lock,' a key attachment indicating if a door is locked (red) or open (green); and 'Nipper,' described as the world's smallest mobile phone charger using household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter using #everydayfix, and the winner will be funded through Kickstarter for development. Other designs that didn't make the shortlist included a cycling helmet with bone conduction headphones, a parking pin alert system, and an app to relay messages when a phone battery dies.

A large-scale Finnish study found that babies given antibiotics within the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The study, involving over 12,000 children, observed that by age two, children who had received antibiotics early, or had repeated prescriptions, had increased odds of being overweight, with boys seeming particularly prone. Researchers suggest antibiotics might alter gut bacteria, potentially increasing food absorption or appetite, and contributing to the childhood obesity epidemic. Lead author Dr. Antti Saari emphasized the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy due to these potential unintended consequences, despite the crucial role of antibiotics in health.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover while taking position in his sentry box during the Changing of the Guard ceremony. The incident occurred in front of hundreds of tourists and was recorded on camera by holidaymaker David Meadwell. The guard, who appeared embarrassed, quickly scrambled to his feet. It is thought that metal protectors on his boots may have caused the slip on the manhole cover. The Ministry of Defence stated they would not comment on the incident.

The 1977 miniseries "Roots," about an African-American slave named Kunta Kinte and his descendants, is being remade by A&E networks (A&E, Lifetime, History) to air in 2016. The remake will be simulcast on the three networks. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version, which is described as "original" and "contemporary." It will draw more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family" and consult scholars for authenticity. The aim is to bring the story to fans of the original and a new generation.

Police are investigating claims made by Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, that palace aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978. Lawler alleges that on his first day, he was pinned to a chair and groped by male staff members. He states he left the job the same day after reporting the incident and being threatened. Lawler contacted palace officials again last year, prompted by inquiries into historical child sex abuse cover-ups, but claims his complaints were ignored for months before the police were notified. Scotland Yard is now investigating the allegations, and the Royal Household has stated it will cooperate fully with the probe.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child via a rap video parodying the theme song from 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. The video, featuring the couple rapping in a car about buying their first house, questions about parenthood, trying to conceive, and discovering the pregnancy, ends with them sharing a sonogram. Filmed in five takes and intended for faraway loved ones, the clip received over 1.7 million YouTube views, a success the couple found unexpected. They told KPTV they might make another video after finding out the child's gender. Melissa had previously made a video capturing Jesse's reaction to learning the news via a tag placed on their dog. Another couple from Pennsylvania also used the 'Fresh Prince' theme for a pregnancy announcement last year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, featuring a black zigzag applique, was worn in several key scenes but has faded from its original slate blue-gray color. The dress was part of over 150 items auctioned from the private collection of James Tumblin, who bought the dress for $20 in the 1960s when it was about to be discarded. Other items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000), and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000). A two-year-old boy fell 10-12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents reportedly dangled him over the railing and he slipped from his mother's grasp. The parents rescued the child from the pit before emergency services arrived. The boy suffered minor injuries from the fall, including bumps, bruises, and a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs. He was taken to the hospital and is listed in stable condition. Based on eyewitness accounts, the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family and closed the exhibit following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which previously enforced a 30mph limit, has been turned to point directly at a house's front door. This camera, along with around 300 fixed devices across the West Midlands, has not been operational for over two years, having been switched off in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. Speed enforcement is currently conducted by mobile units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the repositioned camera, will send an engineer to the site, and may remove it completely. There are plans for a pilot using new digital technology at some sites, but this specific camera is not included. It is unknown who repositioned the camera.

Usain Bolt will compete as part of the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2nd and 3rd, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA). Bolt confirmed he is "fit, healthy and ready to run" and mentioned Jamaica's successful relay tradition and his pride in representing the country. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure that Bolt would be running for Jamaica. The full team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves attended the Barcelona versus Real Madrid basketball El Clasico, which Barcelona won 85-80. Neymar's sister Rafaella was also present. Despite the loss, Real Madrid remained top of their Euro League division based on points difference. Prior to this, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile, enduring several challenges during the match, including an apparent stamp by Gary Medel. Before the international break, Luis Enrique's Barcelona football team won their El Clasico, establishing a four-point lead in La Liga. They are scheduled to play Celta Vigo next as they continue their pursuit of a treble.

However, the Italian coast guard could not confirm this specific incident and found no evidence of it despite searching. There has been a recent upsurge in migrant crossings and rescues.
